*Comment posted by [LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com)*
All is ok now + the LGTM alerts have been fixed. @ogrisel, @jnothman : it is now ready for a second round of review.

Thanks for the review @NicolasHug. 

 * concerning the plots in the example, I did include them in [a message above](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/12069#issuecomment-424297468) (note: you have to ask github to load all hidden items in the middle of this conversation), and commited a dedicated example to reproduce the plots. One can visually detect no difference.

 * Very good catch concerning #12143 and #12145: indeed they popped up when I added the randomized method. The main reason seems that the randomized method seems to naturally find the "perfect zero eigenvalues" while arpack and dense methods most of the time find a tiny non-zero number instead (e.g. of the order of magnitude of 1e-16 if my memory is correct). So when I tried the new method on random data I quickly found the first zero eigenvalue, which made the division by zero bug appear. For the record this is why I actually struggled quite a lot to find [a small example reproducing the zero division bug with dense method](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/12141#issuecomment-427752381) :)

 * Concerning the improvement, the benchmark plot already shows 4x faster running times for small amount of dimensions (a gain which is much smaller on the 2D example I admit), but on real-world timeseries data, on matlab environment, we found out that the randomized method could speed up running times more than 10 times and sometimes (very large datasets), it would make a decomposition computable when it would not be computable at all with the full decomposition method because of memory issues. 

 * Finally this PR is an open road to integrate the lobpcg solver too by [adding these 6 lines in `_fit_transform`](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/12319/files#diff-4143e2be661b19bdff49616c76de91c3R538). I did not do it yet because I wanted to be sure that it would be ok to add it in the same PR, and I am still not sure if it brings better results (did not make the test yet) ; but it makes a lot of sense because that would make `KernelPCA` completely consistent in terms of solvers, with the solvers in `PCA` and `TruncatedSVD`. At least that's what [the author of lobpcg suggests](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/12068#issuecomment-424089267).

Just for information, are we supposed to add ourselves in the authors names list at the top of the file when we propose such PRs ?
Thanks again for the careful reviews.

We have no strict rules about authors lists in files. If you feel you made
a substantial contribution to the file and want to be credited and
ultimately contacted for your work, you can add your name.

I imagined another experiment to show the benefits of this PR: I generate an increasingly big number of samples (from 100 to 10000), and perform a KernelPCA decomposition to always get the first 100 components from it. In practice 100 components are enough to get a fairly good approximation of the underlying distribution for many real-world datasets - even if you have more data to provide you should not need many more components to describe them. The execution times speak for themselves:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3236794/47025807-797d7500-d164-11e8-912e-4682e27b018b.png)

EDIT: another run with arpack:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3236794/47029170-2b1fa480-d16b-11e8-8480-e8d71f2900bb.png)

Thanks for the update. Dumb question: those plots are using your current PR's code, not matlab, right?

BTW you can  include benchmark code (if you deem necessary) with a github gist or by using a `<details> ... </details>` tag.

issues.title: [MRG] Openml data loader
issues.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-checklist
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.
Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Fixes #9543 Fixes #9908
This is the work I performed on issue #9543,
building upon the work that @amueller wants to merge in #9908

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Adds an OpenMl data loader

#### Any other comments?
Builds upon the work of @amueller. the latest version of liac-arff package is packed in externals and the unit tests are more extensive. 

<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is
necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value
all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to
review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering,
convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either
case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
For more information, see our FAQ on this topic:
http://scikit-learn.org/dev/faq.html#why-is-my-pull-request-not-getting-any-attention.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

**TO DO AFTER MERGE:**

* require version when fetching by name, or at least raise a warning along the lines of "Multiple dataset versions match the name BLAH. Versions may be very different. Getting version x."
* Multilabel datasets which encode their targets as nominals do not work with scikit-learn estimators, since `Y` consists of strings. We should maybe identify multilabel data, at least when its values are all {FALSE, TRUE} and encode it to {0, 1}.
* complete #11466 by using `fetch_openml` in examples in place of fetch_mldata
* new issue about caching decoded ARFF
* new issue about checking dataset integrity with respect to stated number of instances, etc. or just use an  MD5 check
* resolve TODOs/FIXMEs
* support `return_X_y`
* add an option to one-hot encode nominals
* add an option to ignore some features, or all STRING attributes
* support returning dataframes (with what API?)
* separate out a `load_arff` function?
* use compressed HTTP requests as in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3947120/does-python-urllib2-automatically-uncompress-gzip-data-fetched-from-webpage

I am running into a problem with the example `mice` data: it seems to skip the non-numerical features:

```
In [3]: mice = fetch_openml(name='miceprotein', version=4) 

In [8]: mice.data.shape
Out[8]: (1080, 77)

In [9]: len(mice.features)
Out[9]: 82

Out[10]: 77

In [12]: len([feat['data_type'] for feat in mice.features if feat['data_type'] == 'numeric'])
Out[12]: 77

In [13]: len([feat['data_type'] for feat in mice.features if feat['data_type'] == 'nominal'])
Out[13]: 5
```

So 4 nominal features seem to have been dropped from the returned data (1 of the 5 is the target). 

I think in those cases (mixed numeric and nominal) we should return an object dtype array by default (and ideally have an option to return a dataframe)

Hmm, coming back to my comment above: that seems to be because those nominal features are tagged with `'is_ignore': 'true'`. 
So I suppose in this case that was correct behaviour.

And with eg titanic it is correctly returning an object dtyped array.
@jorisvandenbossche @amueller @rth @jnothman Unless I forgot something all your comments have been addresses. Feel free to criticize

Since it is crazy hard to setup my own windows environment, I wrote the following piece of code that is executed on both Travis and Appveyor. It asserts that the directory structure of the mocked files is correctly setup, and that all files are reachable. 

```
def test_mocked_testfiles_exist():
    data_ids = [2, 61, 292, 561, 40675]
    expected_files = ['data.arff.gz', 'data_description.json.gz',
                      'data_features.json.gz']
    assert os.path.isdir(currdir)
    assert os.path.isdir(os.path.join(currdir, 'mock_openml'))
    for data_id in data_ids:
        test_dir = os.path.join(currdir, 'mock_openml', str(data_id))
        assert os.path.isdir(test_dir)
        assert len(os.listdir(test_dir)) >= 5
        for expected_file in expected_files:
            assert os.path.isfile(os.path.join(test_dir, expected_file))
```

issues.title: FEA Add Self Training Estimator
issues.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #1243.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Implements a meta classifier for semi-supervised learning based on the original Yarowsky self-training algorithm (refer to http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P95-1026 for details).
Here is a comparison graph of our implemented version on the IRIS dataset. You can find the code under `examples/semi_supervised/plot_self_training_performance.py`.
![Comparison Graph](https://35903-843222-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/doc/_images/sphx_glr_plot_self_training_performance_001.png)


#### Any other comments?
This PR was created in collaboration of @oliverrausch.
This PR is a work in progress and we'd continue working on it if you would be willing to merge once it is completed.

comments_data.body: I think I failed to post an issue, but I've also recently seen work that mentions the effectiveness of [tri-training](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/iel5/69/32375/01512038.pdf). Do you know anything about the relative effectiveness of these models? I suppose tri-training is harder to define for regression...

For now we've only been testing the simpler, original self-training algorithm which is in this PR, but implementing something similar to tri-training or [co-training](https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=279962) seems like a natural next step once this feature is done.
Tri-training looks promising in the paper (outperforming self-training), this might be something we could work on after finishing this PR

Well, you'd be best pinging in a few weeks, as we are currently trying to
push out a release.​
Sure, that works for us. Is this generally a feature you would potentially include (once it is done)?

>  Is this generally a feature you would potentially include?

I think it's an area where we should improve our current offerings, yes.
​
All the CI say no! :\
Yes, we will fix that as soon as possible. We have exams for the next two weeks and will get back to it then.
Can't you just delegate to the underlying estimator to check if fitted?

Yes, but I decided against this because this would erroneously report the estimator as fitted if a fitted estimator is passed to the class. This seems like incorrect behavior to me.

I will be adding the predicted labels and the iteration they were labeled as attributes, so I'll check if the estimator is fitted based on those.

> Yes, but I decided against this because this would erroneously report the estimator as fitted if a fitted estimator is passed to the class. This seems like incorrect behavior to me.

You should be storing a clone of the estimator rather than the original, which would avoid this.
We think that the PR is ready for some feedback now.
As a side note, It'd be great if you could take a look at PR #12088, since this would allow me not skip score in `test_metaestimators.py` (something you mentioned in the first review).

I think the issues that you mentioned in the review have been resolved. With regards to the [example](https://33873-843222-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/doc/auto_examples/semi_supervised/plot_self_training_performance.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-semi-supervised-plot-self-training-performance-py), do you think that it is ok now? 

EDIT: the string arrays test was wrong, they do not work atm. I'll be fixing this shortly
Support for string labels should be fixed now. To implement it, I assume that the base_estimator has the `classes_` attribute, but I'm not sure if this is enforced across all classifiers.

I've also added a call to `is_estimator` to the input validation. I'm not sure if this goes against the "spirit" of duck typing, so if you prefer I can revert it again.

Note that if we decide to keep the call, `test_metaestimators.py` will need to be updated, since the Subestimators it creates do not have the classifier attribute.

EDIT: or maybe I could just raise a warning instead of an error
EDIT2: I've decided against including this and removed it
Tests are failing

Do you think we should support multilabel classification? I was thinking that we could simply add a column to the training data where 1 represents an unlabeled sample (as a replacement for -1 labels in normal classification).
Don't worry about multilabel initially, though it is an interesting question

comments_data.body: @tguillemot @dengemann @raghavrv @ogrisel here we go

The problem is that (feature-wise) scaling stands for deviding each feature by a scalar value. This is the case for `StandardScaler` and `RobustScaler` but not in our case. I prefer `QuantileNormalizer` or `QuantileTransformer`.
https://research.google.com/pubs/pub45530.html uses "quantile normalization" in the body of the article to describe what we do in this class. +1 for `QuantileNormalizer`.

> https://research.google.com/pubs/pub45530.html uses "quantile normalization" in the body of the article to describe what we do in this class. +1 for QuantileNormalizer.

Fair enough. The narration of the User guide needs to be changed to be coherent.

@ogrisel  Would it be possible to kill all appveyor pending checks for that PR despite the last one. I kinda overloaded the CI.

1. `QuantileNormalizer` makes it sound like it's a sample-wise transformation as `Normalizer` is. I would rather `QuantileScaler` or `QuantileTransformer` or `Quantiler` or `RankTransformer`


2. Should sparse normalisation produce the same results as the equivalent dense input? Currently it doesn't, but assumes that the implicit zeros have no effect on the data distribution.
```python
>>> X = sparse.csr_matrix((np.array([0]), np.array([0]), np.array([0, 1])), shape=(1, 1)))
>>> QuantileNormalizer().fit_transform(X).A
array([[ 1.,  0.]])
>>> QuantileNormalizer().fit_transform(X.A)
array([[ 1.,  1.]])
>>> X[0, 0] = 1
>>> QuantileNormalizer().fit_transform(X).A
array([[ 1.,  0.]])
```
Is this the behaviour we want

> Should sparse normalisation produce the same results as the equivalent dense input? Currently it doesn't, but assumes that the implicit zeros have no effect on the data distribution.

The issue is from the `numpy.interp1d` which does crazy stuff at the bounds. Considering the following matrix:

```python
array([[0, 0],
       [0, 0],
       [1, 0]])
```

The sparse output will be:
```python
array([[ 0.,  0.],
       [ 0.,  0.],
       [ 1.,  0.]])
```

For the sparse case, we do not compute the mapping with `interp1d` of the 0s since they will be 0s anyway.

For the dense case, the results is:

```python
array([[ 0.24724725,  1.        ],
       [ 0.24724725,  1.        ],
       [ 1.        ,  1.        ]])
```

which can be reproduce with the following snippet:

```python
reference = np.linspace(0, 1, num=1000)
q = np.percentile(X.A, reference, axis=0)
i0 = interp1d(q[:, 0], reference)
i1 = interp1d(q[:, 1], reference)
print(i0(0))
print(i1(0))
```

You get

```python
0.24724725
1.
```

The hacking to get the same value between dense and sparse is to avoid using `interp1d` for the lower and upper bounds and map them to 0. and 1.

@jnothman @ogrisel @tguillemot  any thoughts?

PS: Just by curiosity, what are we still supporting such old numpy like 1.6. The implementation could have been cleaner with 1.8 support :S

> PS: Just by curiosity, what are we still supporting such old numpy like 1.6. The implementation could have been cleaner with 1.8 support :S

You can wait until May 2017 where Ubuntu 12.04 will not be supported and we will probably upgrade the requirements. There is an issue about that: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/7522.

The bounds introduce wrong computation : 
```python
>>> X = np.array([[0, 0,  1],
                  [1, 0.5, 0]]).T
>>> X1 = np.array([[0, 0, 1],
                   [0.1, 0.5, 0.1]]).T
>>> qn = QuantileNormalizer()
>>> qn.fit(X)
>>> qn.transform(X)
array([[ 0. ,  1. ],
       [ 0. ,  0.5],
       [ 1. ,  0. ]])
>>>qn.transform(X1)
array([[ 0.,  0.],
       [ 0.,  1.],
       [ 1.,  0.]])
```

instead of :
```python
>>>qn.transform(X1)
array([[ 0.,  0.1],
       [ 0.,  0.5],
       [ 1.,  0.1]])
```
I think we can decide to proactively raise the dependency to the numpy  / scipy versions of Ubuntu 14.04 if it's too complex to support the old numpy.

> Should sparse normalisation produce the same results as the equivalent dense input? Currently it doesn't, but assumes that the implicit zeros have no effect on the data distribution.

We probably need an option to switch between the 2 modes: consider non-materialized zeros as missing values to be ignored. I think the default would be to have the missing zeros considered as true zeros and therefore should behave the same as the corresponding model fit on `X.toarray()`.

> I think we can decide to proactively raise the dependency to the numpy / scipy versions of Ubuntu 14.04 if it's too complex to support the old numpy.

This is minor changes such as `tolist()` conversion or use `permutation` instead of `choice`. The code is just easier to read with those functions.

The issue with the bounds will still be there, whatever numpy version.

> We probably need an option to switch between the 2 modes: consider non-materialized zeros as missing values to be ignored. I think the default would be to have the missing zeros considered as true zeros and therefore should behave the same as the corresponding model fit on X.toarray().

Is `ignore_zeros` the right naming? I would think that it could be extended to the other scaler as well.

> Is ignore_zeros the right naming? 

Maybe `ignore_implicit_zeros` is a more explicit name.

> I would think that it could be extended to the other scaler as well.

I don't know. Maybe we should leave that for another PR.
I am fine with using `rng,permutation` instead of choice for now.

Today in today's Parietal meeting @GaelVaroquaux made the excellent suggestion to add an option to map the quantiles to the quantiles of the standard normal distribution. This can be crucial for satisfying the model assumptions of certain types of models. If I'm not mistaken, this would be precisely the case, most trivially, for linear models. Btw. we should also add some documentation here. I think what is implemented here is nothing less then a copula transform. Btw. @robince this maybe of interest to you.

So this is WIP but this is my [solution](https://github.com/glemaitre/scikit-learn/pull/3).
The output PDF can be any `scipy.stats.rv_continuous` with an additional clipping to avoid infinity mapping but such that we can still have a "proper" inverse.

I need to add test

@glemaitre amazing. It looks conceptually clean at first sight. I think it will be a matter of tests. And certainly beyond Gauss there are at least a few more parametric distributions that are used by models, e.g. poisson, binomial etc.

issues.body:
**Reference Issues/PRs**
Propositon to resolve #14214 issue (Since I don't see any other pull request at it is almost 2 years old)

**What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.**
Implements Bisecting K-Means Algorithms

comments_data.body: As @TomDLT suggested here: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/14214#issuecomment-510967687 could you please add a motivation / documentation as why this is a good addition?

@adrinjalali to be honest I treated it as improvement of K-means basing on those documents
- [1A Comparison of Document Clustering Techniques](http://www.philippe-fournier-viger.com/spmf/bisectingkmeans.pdf) - Provided by SSaishruthi in issue #14214
- [Performance Analysis of  K-Means and BisectingK-Means Algorithms in Weblog Data](https://ijeter.everscience.org/Manuscripts/Volume-4/Issue-8/Vol-4-issue-8-M-23.pdf)
- [Bisecting K-Means Algorithm Introduction](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/bisecting-k-means-algorithm-introduction/)
@scikit-learn/core-devs we need a decision on whether to include this algorithm or not. To me it clearly passes the inclusion criteria.

> @scikit-learn/core-devs we need a decision on whether to include this algorithm or not. To me it clearly passes the inclusion criteria.

+1

After investigating which specific algorithm this is (it comes with various names), I agree that it should be included. It is well cited (but that does not suffice to make me enthusiastic). More importantly, it fills in nicely a niche for which we have no tool in scikit-learn. Indeed, experience shows that such approach is preferable to agglomerative clustering if the number of clusters is small compared to the number of data points (that's a comment that could be added to the docs to help users decide which algorithm investigate).

@GaelVaroquaux, @NicolasHug -  I would be glad if you could tell me what can I do about that error `AssertionError: Estimator BisectKMeans doesn't seem to fail gracefully on sparse data: error message should state explicitly that sparse input is not supported if this is not the case.`. ?
Maybe I'm wrong but from my understanding of sparse data it should be accepted by this algorithm

> Maybe I'm wrong but from my understanding of sparse data it should be accepted by this algorithm

Have you verified that with a short test?

If  `check_estimator_sparse_data` properly does what it's supposed to do, the model is failing on sparse data and the error message doesn't contain "sparse", so it's judged as an  uninformative error message.
That's probably unrelated to your changes, try merging with the main branch maybe?
Thanks @NicolasHug - Seems a bit messy now, but worked. Could I ask you or @GaelVaroquaux to make another review?

Hi @michalkrawczyk, it looks like you merged your branch in your local `main` branch rather than the other way around (and then somehow pushed it on your remote branch), explaining the noticeable diff on a few hundreds files.

To correct this, I would recommend (I haven't verified that this works though):
 - to make sure your `main` is identical to upstream's
 ```sh
 git branch -D main
 git fetch upstream
 # or origin, based on your naming, ie.
 # git fetch origin
 git checkout main
```
 - to keep a old copy of your current branch:
 ```sh
 git branch -m bisect_k_means old/bisect_k_means
 ```
 - to create another local `bisect_k_means` branch starting from db674e4
```sh
git checkout db674e4
git checkout -b bisect_k_means
```
 - to [cherry-pick](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-cherry) commits ahead of db674e4  and related to your proposals (74f7006, 0b0fa45a75c2e89b0f0057d4102f6ab69a74e467, 25183fc, d4ea5f5)
  - to merge `main` in your branch
```sh
git merge main
```
  - to inspect if the patches' difference is correct with:
  ```sh
  git diff main..bisect_k_means
  ```
  - **if and only if it is correct** to [force push with lease](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-push#Documentation/git-push.txt---force-with-leaseltrefnamegtltexpectgt) to correct this PR
  ```sh
  git push your_remote --force-with-lease bisect_k_means:bisect_k_means
  ```

I've managed to sort this out on my machine (see details bellow showing the diff between `main` and this branch). We can have a quick call so that you can recover a proper state for your branch (ping me a email).
See the patches The following patches have been extracted, after running the previous commands given above, with:

```sh git format-patch main --stdout ```

```diff From 44d8446e8dfcb18970b6b61edffd944bfa10a96c Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001 From: michalkrawczyk Date: Thu, 29 Apr 2021 21:16:03 +0200 Subject: [PATCH 01/16] Dirty Bisecting K-Means Init --- sklearn/cluster/_bisect_k_means.py | 148 +++++++++++++++++++ sklearn/cluster/tests/test_bisect_k_means.py | 33 +++++ 2 files changed, 181 insertions(+) create mode 100644 sklearn/cluster/_bisect_k_means.py create mode 100644 sklearn/cluster/tests/test_bisect_k_means.py diff --git a/sklearn/cluster/_bisect_k_means.py b/sklearn/cluster/_bisect_k_means.py new file mode 100644 index 0000000000..ff51270be3 --- /dev/null +++ b/sklearn/cluster/_bisect_k_means.py @@ -0,0 +1,148 @@ +import warnings + +import numpy as np +from sklearn.utils.validation import check_X_y, check_array, check_is_fitted, _check_sample_weight, check_random_state +from ..utils.extmath import row_norms +from ._kmeans import KMeans, _kmeans_single_elkan, _kmeans_single_lloyd, _labels_inertia_threadpool_limit + + +class BisectKMeans(KMeans): + def __init__(self, n_clusters: int = 8, n_init: int = 10, random_state=None, + max_iter: int = 300, verbose=0, tol=1e4): + + super().__init__( + n_clusters=n_clusters, max_iter=max_iter, verbose=verbose, + random_state=random_state, tol=tol, n_init=n_init) + + def _calc_squared_errors(self, X, centers, labels): + """ + Calculates SSE of each point and assign them by label + """ + labels_by_index = [[], []] + + for x in range(0, len(labels)): + if labels[x] == 0: + labels_by_index[0].append(x) + else: + labels_by_index[1].append(x) + + sse = {} + + for index, labels in enumerate(labels_by_index): + sse[index] = ((X[labels] - centers[index]) ** 2).sum(axis=1) + + return sse + + def _check_params(self, X): + super()._check_params(X) + + if self.n_clusters < 3: + warnings.warn("BisectKMeans is inefficient for n_cluster smaller than " + " - Use Normal KMeans from sklearn.cluster instead") + + def fit(self, X, y=None, sample_weight=None): + """Compute bisecting k-means clustering. + + Parameters + ---------- + X : {array-like, sparse matrix} of shape (n_samples, n_features) + + Training instances to cluster. + + .. note:: The data will be converted to C ordering, + which will cause a memory copy + if the given data is not C-contiguous. + + y : Ignored + Not used, present here for API consistency by convention. + sample_weight : array-like of shape (n_samples,), default=None + The weights for each observation in X. If None, all observations + are assigned equal weight. + + Returns + ------- + self + Fitted estimator. + """ + X = self._check_test_data(X) + + self._check_params(X) + self.random_state = check_random_state(self.random_state) + sample_weight = _check_sample_weight(sample_weight, X, dtype=X.dtype) + + n_iter = 0 + + data_left = X + centroids = [] + + while n_iter < self.max_iter: + child = KMeans( + n_clusters=2, n_init=self.n_init, max_iter=self.max_iter, + tol=self.tol, verbose=self.verbose, random_state=self.random_state, + copy_x=self.copy_x, algorithm=self._algorithm).fit(data_left) + + sse = self._calc_squared_errors(X, child.cluster_centers_, child.labels_) + + lower_sse_index = 0 if sse[0].sum(axis=0) < sse[1].sum(axis=0) else 1 + higher_sse_index = int(not lower_sse_index) + + centroids.append(child.cluster_centers_[lower_sse_index]) + + if len(centroids) + 1 == self.n_clusters: + centroids.append(child.cluster_centers_[higher_sse_index]) + break + + data_left = data_left[[x for x in range(len(child.labels_)) if child.labels_[x] == higher_sse_index]] + + n_iter += 1 + + if n_iter == self.max_iter: + raise RuntimeError("Number of iteration exceeded maximum allowed") + + x_squared_norms = row_norms(X, squared=True) + + _centers = np.asarray(centroids) + + if self._algorithm == "full": + self._kmeans_single = _kmeans_single_lloyd + self._check_mkl_vcomp(X, X.shape[0]) + else: + self._kmeans_single = _kmeans_single_elkan + + self.labels_, self.inertia_, self.cluster_centers_, self.n_iter_ = self._kmeans_single( + X, sample_weight, _centers, self.max_iter, + self.verbose, x_squared_norms, self.tol, self._n_threads + ) + + return self + + def predict(self, X, sample_weight=None): + """Predict the closest cluster each sample in X belongs to. + In the vector quantization literature, `cluster_centers_` is called + the code book and each value returned by `predict` is the index of + the closest code in the code book. + + Parameters + ---------- + X : {array-like, sparse matrix} of shape (n_samples, n_features) + New data to predict. + sample_weight : array-like of shape (n_samples,), default=None + The weights for each observation in X. If None, all observations + are assigned equal weight. + + Returns + ------- + labels : ndarray of shape (n_samples,) + Index of the cluster each sample belongs to. + """ + check_is_fitted(self) + + X = self._check_test_data(X) + x_squared_norms = row_norms(X, squared=True) + sample_weight = _check_sample_weight(sample_weight, X, dtype=X.dtype) + + labels, _ = _labels_inertia_threadpool_limit( + X, sample_weight, x_squared_norms, + self.cluster_centers_, n_threads=self._n_threads) + + return labels diff --git a/sklearn/cluster/tests/test_bisect_k_means.py b/sklearn/cluster/tests/test_bisect_k_means.py new file mode 100644 index 0000000000..987b93d894 --- /dev/null +++ b/sklearn/cluster/tests/test_bisect_k_means.py @@ -0,0 +1,33 @@ +import unittest +import numpy as np +from .._bisect_k_means import BisectKMeans +from numpy.testing import assert_array_equal + + +class MyTestCase(unittest.TestCase): + def test_bicluster(self): + X = np.array([[1, 2], [1, 4], [1, 0], + [10, 2], [10, 4], [10, 0]]) + + bisect_means = BisectKMeans(n_clusters=2, random_state=0) + bisect_means.fit(X) + + expected_centers = [[1, 2], [10, 2]] + assert_array_equal(expected_centers, bisect_means.cluster_centers_) + assert_array_equal(bisect_means.predict([[0, 0], [12, 3]]), [0, 1]) + + def test_three_clusters(self): + X = np.array([[1, 2], [1, > fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/': Failed to connect to github.com port 443: Connection timed out

?

It looks rather unrelated to your PR: Azure CI requests to GitHub timed out (it happens sometimes).

If the pipeline is ran again (when you push new commits for instance) this might get resolved.
I guess I've done all that's should be done. May I ask somebody for another review?

> This implementation seems incorrect. I don't know the original algorithm, but here the bisection only considers the previously split clusters as the next clusters to be potentially split, while I would expect the algorithm to reconsider all clusters at each bisection.
> 
> For instance, here is the result of running this implementation on the example `plot_digits_kmeans`:
> ...
> 
> What paper are you implementing?

@TomDLT It's the way it should be implemented. Look for example here [Bisecting K-Means](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/bisecting-k-means-algorithm-introduction/). That way it can produce more hierarchical clustering

Based on the [original paper](http://www.philippe-fournier-viger.com/spmf/bisectingkmeans.pdf):
>#### Basic Bisecting K-means Algorithm for finding K clusters. 
>1. Pick a cluster to split.
>2. Find 2 sub-clusters using the basic K-means algorithm. (Bisecting step) 
>3. Repeat step 2, the bisecting step, for ITER times and take the split that produces the clustering with the highest overall similarity.   
>4. Repeat steps 1, 2 and 3 until the desired number of clusters is reached. 
>
>There are a number of different ways to choose which cluster is split. For example, we can choose the largest cluster at each step, the one with the least overall similarity, or use a criterion based on both size and overall similarity. We did numerous runs and determined that the differences between methods were small. In the rest of his paper we split the largest remaining cluster.

Note step 1: "**Pick a cluster to split**". In your implementation, this step is always done out of the two most recently split clusters. Instead, we should pick the next cluster to split out of the entire set of clusters, implementing one of the two selection methods proposed, either the largest cluster, or the one with the least overall similarity.

> > There are a number of different ways to choose which cluster is split. For example, we can choose the largest cluster at each step, the one with the least overall similarity, or use a criterion based on both size and overall similarity. We did numerous runs and determined that the differences between methods were small. In the rest of his paper we split the largest remaining cluster.
> 
> Note step 1: "**Pick a cluster to split**". In your implementation, this step is always done out of the two most recently split clusters. Instead, we should pick the next cluster to split out of the entire set of clusters, implementing one of the two selection methods proposed, either the largest cluster, or the one with the least overall similarity.

I've spotted some different picking tactics as e.g picking by least number of centroids , but that I've picked seems to be most popular. Maybe It should also be considered to allow other picking methods in the future.

The way I've implemented it - it firstly find pair of clusters with lowest inertia from data left to cluster. I quite don't undestand you at this point, cause if you spilit out entire set of cluster you would give up with bisection (which is essence of this algorithm) or if you just pick from all calculated clusters the one that seem to achieve best and worst SSE (or other checked metrics) - They may have been no more themselves after reassiging points to those centroids

> I've spotted some different picking tactics as e.g picking by least number of centroids , but that I've picked seems to be most popular. Maybe It should also be considered to allow other picking methods in the future.

It goes back to a point that I was making earlier: we really need a
traceable reference that details what this PR is implement. If they are
variants, and this PR is implementing one of the variants, we need a
traceable justification of the choice across these variants.

> 
>> I've spotted some different picking tactics as e.g picking by least number of centroids , but that I've picked seems to be most popular. Maybe It should also be considered to allow other picking methods in the future.

> It goes back to a point that I was making earlier: we really need a traceable reference that details what this PR is implement. If they are variants, and this PR is implementing one of the variants, we need a traceable justification of the choice across these variants.

Also because I found them only as single mentions without any comparison.
I wanted to attach references at end of docstring, cause I consider them as good for fast checks (if they're well described). Unfortunately some longer links tends to break tests

issues.title: [MRG] Successive halving for faster parameter search

labels.name: High Priority
labels.description: High priority issues and pull requests

issues.body:
Closes #12538 

This implements hyper parameter search with [successive halving](https://amueller.github.io/dabl/dev/user_guide.html#searching-optimal-parameters-with-successive-halving)

~This builds upon #13145, whose changes are required.~

This is a port of what we implemented in dabl with @amueller.

- [X] main functional tests
- [X] examples
- [X] user guide
- [x] better integration into user guide to avoid redundancy
- [x] a few more doc here and there
- [x] some more thorough tests about input checking, etc


~~Still WIP but very advanced, and would appreciate some feedback before I start tackling the last few bullet points, so I'll mark as MRG.~~

ping @ogrisel ;)

------

## Benchmarks

EDIT more recent benchmarks [here](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/13900#issuecomment-584238915)

Please check out [dabl benchmarks](https://github.com/amueller/dabl/tree/master/benchmarks) for source.

- On 20_news_group datset:

```
                    training time   test score   best CV score
---------------------------------------------------------------
GridSearchCV             19984.9 s      0.8567          0.9262
GridSuccessiveHalving      598.4 s      0.8514          0.8811
---------------------------------------------------------------
Best Params GridSuccessiveHalving
{'clf__C': 1000.0, 'vect': TfidfVectorizer(), 'vect__ngram_range': (1, 1)}
Best Params GridSearchCV
{'clf__C': 1000.0,
  'vect': TfidfVectorizer(ngram_range=(1, 2)),
  'vect__ngram_range': (1, 2)}
```

- on digits dataset:

```

Training Time Successive Halving 3.1159074306488037
Test Score Successive Halving:  0.9911111111111112
Parameters Successive Halving:  {'C': 100.0, 'gamma': 0.1}

Training Time Grid Search:  39.42753505706787
Test Score Grid Search:  0.9911111111111112
Parameters Grid Search:  {'C': 10.0, 'gamma': 0.1}
```

comments_data.body:
Most of it is docs, though ;)

One thing that should be noted is that there is no literature on successive halving with a fixed number of configurations as far as I'm aware, or at least not with a fixed number of iterations and a variable budget. So some of the solutions for applying this for grids are solutions Nicolas and I came up with.
@jnothman 	do you have any comment/concern regarding the fact that I pulled the changes from #13145 (which you reviewed)?

> @jnothman do you have any comment/concern regarding the fact that I pulled the changes from #13145 (which you reviewed)?

Are you just asking whether I am happy with those API changes? I appreciate that some kind of protected (in the Java sense) API change is necessary, and that it's hard to design the right change. All in all, I'd like to take a look at this PR, but I've not had a lot of time for review.
Should we consider just calling the estimator `HalvingSearchCV`?

They're named `GridHalvingSearchCV` and `RandomHalvingSearchCV`.

Are you suggesting that we only support the random one?
Let's call it `rate` rather than `ratio`?
Let's call it `rate` rather than `ratio`?
I'm happy with rate. @amueller 	?

I'll review in a bit.
I saw a comment on using the word Halving and not having the default be a ratio/rate of 2. Not sure where that went.
This is indeed strange, but this is what the literature uses.
People often use Hyperband instead of Successive Halving, but empirically Successive Halving seems to be more effective. Using a more complex technique because of better naming seems a bit odd, though ;)

A note on calling cv.split in each iter: if it's a randomised splitter with the default random_state=None, and we are budgeting on n_estimators or whatever, we'll be doing a different split in each iter.

@jnothman 	@amueller thanks for your reviews so far.
the user guide has been significantly updated.

Parameters have been renamed:

- r_min : min_resources
- max_budget : max_resources
- budget_on : resource

attribute r_i is not resources_iter
Great!

Also @jnothman 

- groups aren't supported anymore (maybe just for now?): it is unclear what subsampling with a group means. An option would be to subsample by stratifying over the cross product of classes and groups, but maybe for later
- I added support for `fit_params`. I am not sure how to properly test that the subsampling of the arrays is correct though.

From the contexts where I've used group CV, there should be no problem sampling from within a group. Groups are only about making sure that the evaluation regime is reasonable with respect to data correlations.
@jnothman yes, but we also want to stratify usually and that makes things trickier. I think there's little harm in not supporting groups for now and adding that later.
Thanks a lot for the comments, I'll address them soon. LMK if my answers make any sense

I have played a bit with Adult Census and Histogram GBM here:

https://gist.github.com/ogrisel/254f959c2122ddfb84bbc57f46f9b5a5

I have tried both with `n_samples` and `max_iter`. I can successfully get a speed-up around 2x to 3x w.r.t. traditional `RandomizedSearchCV` with 100 candidates. If both cases it seems that a 2 round halving strategy with a ratio of 10 works well.

- First round: `n_candidates=100` and `max_iter=10` or `n_samples=10%`
- Second round: `n_candidates=10` and `max_iter=100` or `n_samples=100%`

Lower ratios tend to yield to low `min_resources` values which can in turn favor too high learning rate models (when `resource="max_iter"`) or too heavily regularized models when `resource="n_samples"` in the first rounds leading to sub-optimal parameters for the final value of `max_iter` or `n_samples`.

@amueller @NicolasHug I wonder what are you own experiences with this search strategy? Which parametrizations tend to yield good speed-ups vs a random search baseline?

Thanks a lot for your experiments @ogrisel 

> Lower ratios tend to yield to low min_resources values

I'm a bit confused here because the ratio has no effect on min_resources unless force_exhaust_resources is True, but I don't see it being set in your script?


> Lower ratios tend to yield to low min_resources values which can in turn favor too high learning rate models (when resource="max_iter") or too heavily regularized models when resource="n_samples" in the first rounds leading to sub-optimal parameters for the final value of max_iter or n_samples.

That's a very interesting observation. The general idea is that you want your amount of resource at the first iterations to still be enough for discriminating between good and bad models (good and bad meaning, evaluated with more resources). We say something about it in the user guide but I'll emphasize with your example.

I haven't played myself too much with it honestly. I think that a ratio of 10 is pretty high. From the hyperband paper it seems that 3 is usually a good starting point (but hyperband is basically a grid search over the ratio so it is variable)

> I'm a bit confused here because the ratio has no effect on min_resources unless force_exhaust_resources is True, but I don't see it being set in your script?

Hum, I had tried both `force_exhaust_resources=True` and the default and I was probably confused myself.

> I haven't played myself too much with it honestly. I think that a ratio of 10 is pretty high. From the hyperband paper it seems that 3 is usually a good starting point (but hyperband is basically a grid search over the ratio so it is variable)

I believe the hyperband paper is reusing warm_started models in all its experiments.

Without a support of `warm_start=True`, I was not able to get any meaningful speed-up compared to randomized search CV.

Maybe we should try to implement the support for `warm_start=True` first because otherwise it's hard to find settings for HRS that yield a significant speed-up over vanilla RS.

comments_data.body: @jnothman @amueller @GaelVaroquaux It is what I had in mind.
‎Example and doc coming very soon :D
It is very nice that you started this @glemaitre. If you need any help don't hesitate to ping me.

> It is very nice that you started this @glemaitre. If you need any help don't hesitate to ping me.

Actually, it was some good PR which allow us to fix some issues. I would appreciate if you can make a review :)

@amueller I drafted the documentation as well as an example. I hope that it will motivate you to give a go for the review ;)

NB: we should improve the example once the `ColumnTransformer` is merged. There is a huge case in which we applied different classifier on different column and use that as `estimators`. This is more the use case that I am used too actually.

Artifacts for the documentation:

- [user guide](https://22857-843222-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/doc/modules/ensemble.html#stacked-generalization)
-  API [here](https://22857-843222-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/doc/modules/generated/sklearn.ensemble.StackingClassifier.html#sklearn.ensemble.StackingClassifier) and [here](https://22857-843222-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/doc/modules/generated/sklearn.ensemble.StackingRegressor.html#sklearn.ensemble.StackingRegressor)
- [Example](https://22857-843222-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/doc/auto_examples/ensemble/plot_stack_predictors.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-ensemble-plot-stack-predictors-py)

I see that there some glitches to be corrected.

> Your implementation does not allow to pass X unchanged to the final estimator, does it?

It does not allow it. What do you propose. I see 2 solutions:

* Create a keyword "passthrough=True/False" and stack X accordingly
* Create a strategy "input" for the DummyRegressor which will return the input and can be added to the `estimators` list.

The first one is less complicated to discover as a user I think. WDYT?

> The first one is less complicated to discover as a user I think.

I agree.
Don't forget the `    .. versionadded:: 0.20` label in both new classes docstrings.

> Your implementation does not allow to pass X unchanged to the final estimator, does it?

I'm not using stacking extensively, but IMHO this PR is complex enough; since passing `X` to the final estimator may not be the primary reason people would use stacking, maybe this feature can be proposed in a separate PR?
@TomDLT @rth I added the feature and the according tests.
@rasbt might have some insights as well regarding the API?

Caio, at this point I think we would be better including something than
nothing and I am somewhat ambivalent about whether to go for a simplified
interface in the core library, but it seems that is the preference of other
core devs.

@rasbt, I don't understand the issue you have with parameter search in a
simplified interface. Please give an example on @glemaitre's PR.

> @rasbt, I don't understand the issue you have with parameter search in a
simplified interface. Please give an example on @glemaitre's PR.

I am not sure if that is also an issue in this implementation. But in the past, I got several emails from users that tried to/wanted to do sth like the following (note that this is a simplified example translated into the current implementation):

```python
estimators = [('lr', LogisticRegression()), ('svc', LinearSVC())]
final_estimator = ('rf', RandomForestClassifier())
clf = StackingClassifier(estimators=estimators,
                         final_estimator=final_estimator)

params = {'final_estimator__n_estimators': [1, 100],
          'estimators': [[('lr', LogisticRegression()), ('svc1', LinearSVC())],
                         [('lr', LogisticRegression()), ('svc2', SVC())]]}
```

where `params` is then used in `GridSearchCV` etc.

The question would be, when building the grid for `'final_estimator__n_estimators'`, would it be using the original `estimators=estimators` or any of the options `'estimators': ...`?

@jnothman I'd argue having an API __only__ for the simplest use case is not that useful and may be the same as not having it at all. People may still need to resort to external libraries and this implementation may become obsolete or barely used. There's no reason to spend time maintaining something like this. And I'm not even talking about the difference in complexity of the implementation: this implementation has around twice the size of #8960 and only does the bare minimum w.r.t stacked ensembles.

> The question would be, when building the grid for 'final_estimator__n_estimators', would it be using the original estimators=estimators or any of the options 'estimators': ...?

I would think any option of `estimators`. For instance, currently with on of the meta-estimator:

```python
from sklearn.datasets import load_diabetes
from sklearn.compose import TransformedTargetRegressor
from sklearn.model_selection import GridSearchCV
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.linear_model import Lasso

X, y = load_diabetes(return_X_y=True)
ttr = TransformedTargetRegressor()

grid = [{'regressor': [RandomForestRegressor()], 'regressor__n_estimators': [10, 20]},
        {'regressor': [Lasso()], 'regressor__fit_intercept': [False, True]}]
reg = GridSearchCV(ttr, grid)
reg.fit(X, y)
reg.best_estimator_
```
```python
TransformedTargetRegressor(check_inverse=True, func=None, inverse_func=None,
              regressor=RandomForestRegressor(bootstrap=True, criterion='mse', max_depth=None,
           max_features='auto', max_leaf_nodes=None,
           min_impurity_decrease=0.0, min_impurity_split=None,
           min_samples_leaf=1, min_samples_split=2,
           min_weight_fraction_leaf=0.0, n_estimators=20, n_jobs=1,
           oob_score=False, random_state=None, verbose=0, warm_start=False),
              transformer=FunctionTransformer(accept_sparse=False, check_inverse=True, func=None,
          inv_kw_args=None, inverse_func=None, kw_args=None,
          pass_y='deprecated', validate=True))
```

Edit: It is more obvious in the edited example since that the default of the regressor is None which default to a LinearRegression.

@rasbt, I think there are ways to make those set_params things work, by
following the set_params implementation in FeatureUnion etc.​

@glemaitre @jnothman 

> I would think any option of estimators. For instance, currently with on of the meta-estimator:

That's nice! :). Ah, sorry, my previous example was not correct and misleading; what I meant was searching over the `estimators` that are fed to Stacking estimator and the parameters of the estimators provided via `estimators`. E.g., something like

```python
params = {'estimators__lr_C: [0.1, 0.5, 1.0],
                  'estimators': [[('lr', LogisticRegression()), ('svc1', LinearSVC())],
                                        [('lr', LogisticRegression()), ('svc2', SVC())]]}
```

The problem in my implementation was/is that e.g. that settings via `'estimators__lr_C: [0.1, 0.5, 1.0]` will be overwritten by `'estimators': [[('lr', LogisticRegression()), ('svc1', LinearSVC())],...` when I remember correctly. 

Maybe something like this would be good to add as a unit test? Then for

> @rasbt, I think there are ways to make those set_params things work, by
following the set_params implementation in FeatureUnion etc.​

maybe a short section/example in the documentation would help users to avoid pitfalls?

issues.title: [MRG+2] Add fixed width discretization to scikit-learn
issues.body:
# Summary

This PR addresses #5778. It adds the `KBinsDiscretizer` class to scikit-learn.

This PR closes #5825 as a much more straightforward discretization algorithm. It is a WIP, please feel free to leave comments about the current code before the code gets hairy and hard to read 😄 
# Roadmap

Permission
- [x] Package owner approval of algorithm

Features and code
- [x] Uniform discretization strategy for 2D arrays
- [x] `inverse_transform` function
- [x] Unit tests (duh)

Documentation
- [x] User guide
- [x] Docs in `doc/modules/classes.rst`
- [x] Docs in `doc/modules/preprocessing.rst`
- [x] Docstring tests

comments_data.body: The user should be able to provide a mask or indices on what features to bin, right? Also, shouldn't we do uniform bins and percentile bins in the same estimator? It's such a minor change. Any other obvious binning methods we might want to have? What would the estimator be called?
Have you looked at the code, @amueller? I'm not sure this scaling approach to fixed width discretisation easily transfers to quantiles.

@amueller 

> The user should be able to provide a mask or indices on what features to bin, right? 

Yes, that was one feature I didn't include from #5825. I didn't add it into this PR yet - I wanted to keep the PR small, so I could get easy feedback from people whether this is a feasible route to go.

> Also, shouldn't we do uniform bins and percentile bins in the same estimator? It's such a minor change. Any other obvious binning methods we might want to have? What would the estimator be called?

I'm trying to keep it simple like @mblondel's request [here](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/5825#issuecomment-157618119). This PR should only contain binning for `k` fixed bins. I can definitely extend the work more later on.
shouldn't `transform` just be a call to `np.digitize`?

I didn't look at the implementation, but I'm wondering if this relatively complex implementation is actually better than what I would have thought would be the naive one, which is iterating over columns and doing `np.digitize`.
Fit would then be

``` python
mins = np.min(X, axis=0)
maxs = np.max(X, axis=0)
self.bins = [np.linspace(min, max, n_bins + 1) for min, max in zip(mins, maxs)]
```

and `transform` would be

``` python
out = [np.digitize(col, one_bins) for col, bins in zip(X.T, self.bins)]
return OneHotEncoder().fit_transform(np.c_[out])
```

that seems much more readable to me.
The api for percentiles would also be just provide a number of bins, and instead of a linspace we use `np.percentile(X[:, i], np.linspace(0, 100, n_bins + 1))`
I have to admit I didn't think about the sparse case yet.

One of the reasons we were trying to go for a more complex implementation is so we could handle sparse matrices. We wanted any zero in the sparse matrix to map to zero in the discretized matrix.

In the case of using `np.digitize`, we'll have trouble mapping zeros to zeros for negative values. I would otherwise go for a simple implementation.
If you consider sparse matrices @amueller, can you give me a second opinion of my code?

I understand that this "more complex" method allows for a linear time solution.

Is it not straightforward to renumber the bins such that 0 is always in the bin containing 0 in input?

>  Is it not straightforward to renumber the bins such that 0 is always in the bin containing 0 in input?

You can do that. But ultimately what that means is the algorithm will transform a sparse array to a dense array (before another transform to transform it back to a sparse array). This is what we were trying to avoid in #5825. (Which is what led to the long discussion in that PR.)

My solution would preserve the sparsity of the input matrix, which is most ideal. It's complex, but I don't think it's unreadable.

On another note, I don't think `np.digitize` is what we're looking for here. `np.digitize`, prior to `1.10.0`, used a linear search. Also, `np.digitize` wouldn't work for sparse matrices.
[Source](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-dev/reference/generated/numpy.digitize.html).

looks like my standpoint is the opposite of @mblondel's ^^ I'd rather have quantiles and no sparse support and a simple implementation.
Actually, I have to look at this and the previous implementation. I would have expected this transformation to do a one-hot-encoding. What's the point of discretizing without encoding the result as a categorical variable? (Another thing I appear to be disagreeing with @mblondel about https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/5825#issuecomment-156954476)

If we don't do the one-hot-encoding here, this estimator must **always** be followed by a OneHotEncoder - which I find rather strange. Why do we burden the user with that?

And if we one-hot-encode the data, what does that mean for sparse data?

@mblondel can you maybe give an example of your use case? I think I don't understand it.

I though the standard use-case of this would be some continuous features that you want to discretize and then learn a linear model on. That would work well with fixed width and quantiles and (at least with newer numpy) could be done in a couple of lines.

What is the sparse matrix use-case, what data representation do you want to get out and what models do you want to use?

I re-read #5778 and that is actually exactly what I would have thought of. I'm not sure how that relates to sparse input. If we one-hot-encode sparse input, we will have one non-zero entry in the one-hot-encoded version for every entry in the input, also the zero ones. We could add zero as the "reference class" and do a one-hot-encoding where zero is represented by none of the entries set to one. Was that the plan? Currently OneHotEncoder doesn't support that. Also, our OneHotEncoder doesn't support any sparse input, right?
So even if we have sparse matrix support here, there is nothing the user can do with the output without making it dense first.

If you design your bin numbering such that 0 always lands up transforming
0, I don't see how you need to change sparsity: you only need to discretize
the nonzeros. But I suspect that should be special functionality to support
sparse matrices and we should worry about the dense case first.

wrote:

> If we don't do the one-hot-encoding here, this estimator must always be followed by a OneHotEncoder - which I find rather strange. Why do we burden the user with that?

I do agree with you that returning the one-hot encoding is the main use case, as I originally intended in #5778. Returning the ordinal value could be potentially useful for "denoising" the features but I have no evidence of that. 

> @mblondel can you maybe give an example of your use case? I think I don't understand it.

My original use case was to feed the one-hot encoding to models that use feature combinations such as SVMs with a polynomial kernel or factorization machines. However, this was months ago and I don't remember it well.

> If we one-hot-encode sparse input, we will have one non-zero entry in the one-hot-encoded version for every entry in the input, also the zero ones.

I would map zeros to a zero vector. Even if you decide to focus on the dense case for now, it would be nice to keep in mind the sparse case when designing the discretization strategy.

I think it's worth returning ordinals at least initially. Certainly, other
binary encodings, such as [[2], [3]] -> [[1, 1, 0], [1, 1, 1]] are very
useful in practice. It's easy to make a pipeline, but hard if we _only_
offer the output one-hot encoded.

> I would map zeros to a zero vector. Even if you decide to focus on the
> dense case for now, it would be nice to keep in mind the sparse case when
> designing the discretization strategy.

I think this could be counter-intuitive when our one-hot encoder and
others' are inclined to assume bins range from 0 to n_bins - 1. So I'd
rather this be switched on by a keep_zeros_zero=False flag.

issues.title: Enh/tree (performance optimised)
issues.body:
As @satra commented in https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/288#issuecomment-1691949, here is a separate PR for a decision tree.  This version is significantly faster than the alternatives (Orange and MILK). Furthermore, Orange and scikits.learn support multiclass classification and regression, Milk only supports classification.  

We would now welcome any comments with the aim of gaining acceptance for a merge into master. 
## Performance and scores

$python bench_tree.py madelon
Tree benchmarks

Loading data ...
Done, 2000 samples with 500 features loaded into memory
scikits.learn (initial): mean 84.23, std 0.62
Score: 0.76

scikits.learn (now): mean 0.65, std 0.00
Score: 0.76

milk: mean 115.31, std 1.57
Score: 0.75

Orange: mean 25.82, std 0.02
Score: 0.50

$python bench_tree.py arcene
Tree benchmarks

Loading data ...
Done, 100 samples with 10000 features loaded into memory
scikits.learn (initial): mean 40.95, std 0.44
Score: 0.60

scikits.learn (now): mean 0.20, std 0.00
Score: 0.60

milk: mean 71.00, std 0.60
Score: 0.60

Orange: mean 10.78, std 0.20
Score: 0.51
## TODO before merge
- <del>increase test coverage to over 95% </del>
- <del>finish the documentation (fix broken example and plot links, add practical usage tips)</del>
- <del>demonstrate how to use a graphviz output in an example</del>
- <del>include a static grapvhiz output for the iris and boston datasets in the documentation</del>
- <del>add `feature_names` to `GraphvizExporter`</del>
- <del>extract the graphviz exporter code out of the tree classes (use visitor pattern), assign node numbers (not mem addresses)</del>
- <del>s/dimension/feature/g </del>
- <del>add a test for the pickling of a fitted tree</del>
- <del>cythonise prediction</del>
- <del>explain in the documentation and in the docstrings how these classes relate to ID3, C4.5 and CART</del>
## Future enhancements
- ability to provide instance weights (for boosting DTs)
- support a loss matrix (ala R's `rpart`) 
- support multivariate regression (ala R's `mvpart`)
- support Randomized Trees

comments_data.body: Very nice - can't wait to look at that in more detail! thanks @bdholt1, @ndawe, and @satra!
Thanks a lot for the hard work. I think @glouppe will be interested in this branch.

While I've been looking through  neighbors.py, I've noticed a lot of 

```
def fit(self, X, y, **params):
    ...
    self._set_params(**params)
```

to support use within a pipeline.  Should tree.py also support this?
We were just about to [deprecate that](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/306).

Thanks for this work and taking the time to profile and benchmark it against competing implementations. This looks very promising. I will try to secure some time in the coming days to give this PR a deeper look.

I experiment the following broken doctest:

```
----------------------------------------------------------------------
File "/home/ogrisel/coding/scikit-learn/scikits/learn/tree/tree.py", line 474, in scikits.learn.tree.tree.DecisionTreeRegressor
Failed example:
    for train_index, test_index in kf:
        clf = DecisionTreeRegressor()
        clf = clf.fit(data.data[train_index], data.target[train_index])
        print np.mean(np.power(clf.predict(data.data[test_index]) - data.target[test_index], 2))
Expected:
    19.2264679543
    41.2959435867
Got:
    20.2065464252
    44.4226946421

>>  raise self.failureException(self.format_failure(<StringIO.StringIO instance at 0x58dd128>.getvalue()))
```

You should probably use `# doctest: +ELLIPSIS` and `...` markers to replace the lowest decimal values of doctest to void the test to break when switching from one architecture to another.
To fix the previous breakage you should pass a `random_state=0` to the constructor.
I am about to do a first pass at code style cleanup. Expect a pull request soon.
Thanks Olivier!  I've just added some more functionality (bringing this into line with the standard labels accepted for binary classification).  You will probably need to merge.
Hi, I did not have time to come up with a new PR while after my short trip in a plane as I first intended to. I'll let you know when it's ready.

@pprett: The script I used to do the benchmarking is at https://github.com/bdholt1/ml-benchmarks/blob/enh%2Ftree/benchmarks/bench_tree.py

The training set is both madelon and arcene (using the ml-benchmarks framework). 

> >    I started to port the _find_best_split to cython. a quick %timeit clf.fit(X, y) on madelon train turned up 21 sec vs. 99 s per loop for the pure python + numpy implementation

That's great!  This implementation might even get to be the same ballpark speed as Orange, but with the higher score!

Following @pprett's lead, I moved `_find_best_split()` to cython.  A few key insights:
1. Treat classification and regression separately
2. Sort the features and labels, and then work on the sorted arrays.

A significant speed increase: (arcene)

Done, 100 samples with 10000 features loaded into memory
scikits.learn: mean 4.06, std 0.02
Score: 0.57

milk: mean 68.21, std 0.31
Score: 0.25

Orange: mean 10.26, std 0.02
Score: 0.51

All the tests still pass.  This is a 10\* speed increase, making it the fastest of the 3 implementations, while still easy to read and modify.
thanks @satra
nicely done.

@bdholt1 yesterday evening I played around with the second enhancement I told you about (updating the pm counts [or means in regression] vs. computing them from scratch). It turned out that this causes a _massive_ improvement in terms of performance (it's about an order of magnitude or even more):

Madelon:
time: 0:00:00.776095 (that's 0.7 sec)
score: 0.741666666667

Arcene:
time: 0:00:00.125336 (that's 0.1 sec)
score: 0.58

The code is here:
https://github.com/pprett/scikit-learn/tree/bdholt1-enh/tree

When you look at _tree.pyx you see new extension types at the top (`ClassificationCriterion` and `RegressionCriterion`).
They implement the update logic; label counts (aka `pm`) for left and right branch for classification; label means for left and right branch for regression. The concrete subclasses (`Gini`, `Entropy`, and `MSE`) implement an `eval` method which computes the value of the splitting criterion.

+1!  Thats a significant improvement! I suspect it was this very idea that lead to the gain (but clearly not as much) in my previous attempt.  The latest version is also quite a bit more readable.  Given this major gain, I think it warrants some serious attention, so I'll try to work this into my implementation or just use yours straight.

What me strikes is the bad performance of the tree on the Arcene dataset - compared to RBF SVMs (score about 0.73).
Furthermore, I benched it on the covertype dataset (~500k examples, 54 features) -> it's score is similar to that of a linear svm (a non-linear clf should do much better than that!)...

I'm not too surprised about the performance.  Technically a decision tree is more of a non-parametric classifier than non-linear - it works by partitioning up the feature space perpendicular to the dimensions in a greedy fashion, which is quite different to casting it into a higher dimensional space and finding a separating hyperplane...  The good news is that Orange's performance is in the same ballpark, and I've worked through the algorithm quite thoroughly so I'm confident its doing it correctly.  Hopefully we will see a significant performance gain when it comes to using these trees in a forest.  Forests will compete with the best classifiers out there.
Where can I retrieve the Arcene dataset?

http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Arcene

2011/8/24 mblondel
reply@reply.github.com:

> Where can I retrieve the Arcene dataset?
>

> https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/310#issuecomment-1889197

## 

Peter Prettenhofer

issues.title: [MRG] Online implementation of non-negative matrix factorization
issues.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Continues #13386
Aim to fix #13308, fix #13326.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Implement Online non-negative matrix factorization, following
[_Online algorithms for nonnegative matrix factorization with the Itakura-Saito divergence_, A Lefevre, F Bach, C Févotte, 2011](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1106.4198v1.pdf).

comments_data.body:
@GaelVaroquaux , @jeremiedbb this is still WIP but I feel like its status needs an update.
I have rerun benchmarks for commit 0020eb6b4b81fafe45633f9b2b8143377cad627f , the result is below
![bench_topics_drago](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/91660203-323ccb00-ead5-11ea-9dda-a566983bfb83.png)
With respect to the previous implementation:
- I am no longer hardcoding the number of iterations for the minibatch algorithm: the convergence time is still better than for the classical NMF;
- I have introduced the forgetting factor: a 'weight' to be applied to old batches (hardcoded for now).

I have also checked that the minibatch algorithm gives the same results as the single batch one, when the batch size is set to the number of samples (I have added a test for that).

From the plot, the loss is greater in the minibatch implementation, but in some cases it seems to be comparable... I am planning to investigate the role of the forgetting factor on the loss: from Fevotte et al. it seems that this factor and then a good solution, depend on the number of samples and the batch size.

Here what is still needed for this PR:
- [x] investigate the role of the forgetting factor in the loss estimation (~and improve it, hopefully~ it turns out that the expected loss should be investigated instead).
- [x] make the forgetting factor a parameter and suggest possible optimizations depending on the dimensions of the problem
- [x] avoid code duplication (`non_negative_factorization` and `non_negative_factorization_online` are quite the same function right now)
- [x] improve tests (I am open to suggestions for testing [those lines](https://codecov.io/gh/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/compare/576775d6d15b7b69aebd2c464d932c28722eb4a0...6b930d9557a1776730abdd42d4c34c94d61a3d26/src/sklearn/decomposition/_nmf.py?before=sklearn/decomposition/_nmf.py#D1-712))
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/91660689-98c2e880-ead7-11ea-905a-c291f8be8f6e.png)
- [x] write documentation (!)

Thanks for listening and let me know if you have any comment or suggestion.
I can't understand the circleCI lint error....

Thanks @GaelVaroquaux for your comment.
As a starting point I have recycled the script Patricio used for [this plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11759948/53506787-fc212400-3ab6-11e9-8bf6-6267c9faadce.png).
The dataset is split in train and test dataset: the factorization is fitted on the train dataset, then predicted on the test dataset and the correspondent expected loss is computed.
The loss per sample is plotted against convergence time.
It seems to me that at this scale (sample size ~10e5) the problem is less dependent on the forgetting factor than on the batch size.
Two versions of the plot follow:
- n_train = 12000 ; n_test = 7000 (commit 00574c7ce2dd6ce25ac140691e5bbd21d83a2afb)
![benchmark_nmf_blog_authorship_ntrainltntest](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/92370447-97f30d80-f0fa-11ea-8604-0aa51f201bec.png)

- n_train = 7000 ; n_test = 12000 (commit 3104d5e0fe3c3f6634b54e9f6f0a2643c9373a04)
![benchmark_nmf_blog_authorship_ntestltntrain](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/92370622-d12b7d80-f0fa-11ea-904b-a86d3860442c.png)

I guess better out-of-sample losses are expected in the first plot because of the bigger number of samples used for the fit.

That's a super nice plot, @cmarmo !! It really validates the implementation.

It suggests to take batch sizes of 2000 and forgetting factors of .5. Is there any theory on which values are acceptable for forgetting factor? When an algorithm converge in theory for a parameter taken in an interval it is often useful to take a value for this parameter in the middle.

I'm a bit worried that for convergence we need to take huge values of the batch size (typical batch sizes are in the hundreds, not thousands). It seems to point to a variance reduction not happening right. Indeed, large batch sizes reduce the noise in the estimates per batch.

> It suggests to take batch sizes of 2000 and forgetting factors of .5. Is there any theory on which values are acceptable for forgetting factor? When an algorithm converge in theory for a parameter taken in an interval it is often useful to take a value for this parameter in the middle.

Lefèvre, Bach, Févotte 2011, propose an experimental study, which results can be summarized as follows:
- the forgetting factor (r) spans from 1. to 0.5, for r<0.5 the solution is strongly unstable
- if r<1, the batch size (beta) should be chosen large enough
- choosing r=0.7 and beta=10^3 yields satisfactory performance 

> I'm a bit worried that for convergence we need to take huge values of the batch size (typical batch sizes are in the hundreds, not thousands). It seems to point to a variance reduction not happening right. Indeed, large batch sizes reduce the noise in the estimates per batch.

For the sake of completeness here the same plot as before (n_test=7000 n_train=12000) for batch_size = 500
![benchmark_nmf_blog_authorship](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/92399605-d99bac80-f12a-11ea-9132-099f250a3895.png)
I would set r=0.7. It's theoretically motivated, and I seem to remember that it gave us good results.

@jeremiedbb , @GaelVaroquaux , @glemaitre , codecov is finally happy and the failing check is unrelated to my PR. I still need to add more documentation, but I think the code is ready for review. Happy to hear from you all.

> You also have several new blank lines or removed blank lines in places unrelated to the PR that should be reverted imo

I think it's done... I will recheck at the next commit. :)

@jeremiedbb I have committed a version where MiniBatchNMF is inherited from NMF.
The tests on the `transform` function fail with
```
'fit_transform and transform outcomes not consistent in MiniBatchNMF(max_iter=5, random_state=0)'
```
As I said before, I'm still wondering if `transform` is useful in the online implementation: if I understand correctly I have to defined it in the inherited version. Any suggestion? Thanks!

About fit.transform != fit_transform.

- I think we can't expect machine precision equality since fit_transform updates W and H alternatively max_iter times, while fit.transform updates W and H alternatively max_iter times then updates W while keeping H fixed max_iter times.

- In the common tests we safely check equivalence with a low precision (atol=1e-2). Changing it to 1e-3 makes NMF fails, so this issue is not specific to MiniBatchNMF.

- The discrepency is more important with the multiplicative update solver. Switching solver makes the common test fail (even a 1e-2), so it's not catch by the current common test because default is 'cd' but for minibatchnmf it's 'mu' so you trigger the failure.

- The main issue that noticed for the "mu" solver is the difference of initialization between fit and transform.
   In fit, W and H are initialized according to the init parameter, while in transform W is initialized to a constant matrix for 'mu' and to zeros for 'cd'. While for 'cd' it seems to not be a big issue, for 'mu' it is. Mainly, if the init contains zeros at fit time they are propagated all the way while there'll be no zeros at transform time.

I think the issue should be solved separately since it's more general. I'll open an issue
Waiting for #18525.

> I think we can't expect machine precision equality since fit_transform updates W and H alternatively max_iter times, while fit.transform updates W and H alternatively max_iter times then updates W while keeping H fixed max_iter times.

If max_iter is large enough this should work since the problem is strongly convex in W given H, no? (At least for L2 regularization, not sure about the others. But i guess this would be too slow for default values and common tests.

I think a compromise could be to test that if we initialize transform at the true optimum H* (computed via fit_transform with sufficient iters) it does not move it away.
I believe this PR is now in a quite good shape: I have changed WIP to MRG. Waiting for a new run of reviews... also let me know if I have missed some comments.

@TomDLT , while investigating the mismatch between NMF and MiniBatchNMF I realised that [my benchmarks](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/16948#issuecomment-688194782) were significantly slowed down. The reason for that being the increase of the iterations here: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/60d058f01addc6e562bcdeb5607a5d7a54b79acb/sklearn/decomposition/_nmf.py#L1750
I have reduced the number of iteration to 50 and changed the initialization in `partial_fit` obtaining this corresponding plot
![benchmark_nmf_blog_authorship_53c13981](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/103994752-b98eff00-5197-11eb-97ca-aa2d91f8b7bc.png)
to be compared [with this one](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/92370447-97f30d80-f0fa-11ea-8604-0aa51f201bec.png).
Let me know if there is any objection to that.

This hard coded parameter `max_iter` is hard to set optimally for any dataset. I wonder if we shouldn't use `self.max_iter`. It is not used elsewhere with `partial_fit`, so it is probably fine to use it here.
Also, using `tol=0` is probably not great here. I suggest using `tol=1e-4`, or even better, `tol=self.tol`.

For comparison, I'm adding the plot generated with 27f56400268c94caa66694977b8e68a1dee40977
![benchmark_nmf_blog_authorship_27f5640](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1662261/104442193-04908400-5595-11eb-8f25-29019484e96f.png)

Nice! In the docstring, we should say that large batch sizes (several
thousands) give better long-term convergence at the cost of a slower
start.

On Wed, Jan 13, 2021 at 02:49:17AM -0800, Chiara Marmo wrote:
> For comparison, I'm adding the plot generated with 27f5640
> benchmark_nmf_blog_authorship_27f5640

> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.*


-- 
    Gael Varoquaux
    Research Director, INRIA		  Visiting professor, McGill 
    http://gael-varoquaux.info            http://twitter.com/GaelVaroquaux

To improve my understanding I have modified a bit @TomDLT [script](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/16948#discussion_r548134301), to compare the loss difference between standard NMF and MiniBatchNMF with different `batch_size`s. Also, following [previous discussions about empirical and expected losses](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/16948#issuecomment-683733801) I have produced the same plot for both of them, empirical and expected.

<details>
<summary>Empirical loss</summary>

```py
import numpy as np

from sklearn.decomposition._nmf import _beta_divergence
from sklearn.decomposition import NMF
from sklearn.decomposition import MiniBatchNMF

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

rng = np.random.mtrand.RandomState(42)
X = np.abs(rng.randn(48, 5))
batch_size_frac = [0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.]
max_iter_list = np.int_(np.logspace(0, 2.4, 30))
leg_array = []
for bsf in batch_size_frac:
    bs = int(bsf * X.shape[0])
    results = []
    for max_iter in max_iter_list:
        nmf = NMF(5, solver='mu', init='nndsvdar', random_state=0,
                  max_iter=max_iter, beta_loss=2)
        mbnmf = MiniBatchNMF(5, solver='mu', init='nndsvdar', random_state=0,
                             max_iter=max_iter, beta_loss=2,
                             batch_size=bs)

        nmf.fit_transform(X)
        mbnmf.fit_transform(X)

        results.append([(mbnmf.reconstruction_err_ - nmf.reconstruction_err_)/X.shape[0]])

    plt.plot(max_iter_list, np.array(results), '.-')
    str_leg = f'batch_size_frac = {bsf}'
    leg_array.append(str_leg) 
plt.legend(leg_array)
plt.title('Empirical loss')
plt.xlabel('iterations')
plt.ylabel('Reconstruction error difference')
plt.show()
```
</details>
