issues.title: [WIP] Adding tests for estimators implementing `partial_fit` and a few other related fixes / enhancements
issues.body: Fixes #3896 **New `partial_fit` tests:** The below tests are based off @arjoly's [suggestion](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/3896#issuecomment-64862823). - [x] 1. General tests - Assert that `partial_fit` returns `self`. - Thanks @jnothman for [the suggestion.](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/3896#issue-50330161) - Clone test... `assert clone(est).partial_fit == est.partial_fit` - [x] 2. Check that an error is raised if the number of features changes. - [x] 3. Estimator reset test - Check that doing `fit` after a set of `fit` / `partial_fit` restarts the estimator. - Assert that `partial_fit` and then `fit` with a different number of features works without raising any Exceptions... - Thanks @amueller for [the suggestion](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/3907#issuecomment-68411916) - [x] 4. Check if `partial_fit` does not overwrite the previous model. - Based on @jnothman [suggestion](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/3907#issuecomment-68478630) - [x] 5. Check that classifier handles correctly the classes argument in the `partial_fit`. - a. Check if mismatch between `classes` argument and `np.unique(y_i)` raises `ValueError`. - b. Check that error is raised if `classes` is not specified during first `partial_fit` call. - c. Check error is not raised if `classes` is not specified during subsequent calls. - [x] Helper functions - `_validate_y_against_classes` - Check label mismatch between `y` and `classes` arg - `assert_same_model(X, est1, est2)` - `assert_not_same_model(X, est1, est2)` - Use `predict`, `transform`, `decision_function` and `predict_proba` to check equality of models. - In `sklearn.utils.estimator_checks` `_partial_fit` and `_fit` to use the appropriate parameters. - `assert_attributes_equal(est1, est2)` - `assert_attributes_not_equal(est1, est2)` - `assert_array_not_equal` **Refs** Also see #406 - This PR fixes 1st under not so easy for pfit-able estimators, via 3a ( of this PR ) --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/3907)

comments_data.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/1543926/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/1543926)

Coverage remained the same when pulling **79a620bd8b8684c37597a6970fc739c2ec48bf04 on ragv:partial_fit_testing_3896** into **4f1c38179142eb146d633f9e470fc3ae9175a1e8 on scikit-learn:master**.

That seems a nice list (although testing that models are the same currently is done by testing the output of `predict`/`transform`).

I'm not altogether certain about the `fit` then `partial_fit` semantics: `fit` does not necessarily leave the model in a state in which incremental training can occur. I do think that we should decide what correct semantics are.

What is the current semantics?
Should `fit` always leave the model in a state where `partial_fit` is possible?

I am stuck with the 2nd alone... The case when `fit` then `partial_fit` == `partial_fit` then `partial_fit` does not seem to be consistently true. 

( assuming that the equality checks for the accuracy ( `score`) )

Kindly review my current implementation of the other tests.

You should probably use predict/transform directly rather than score, as do the existing invariance tests.

I think `fit, partial fit == partial_fit, partial_fit` is the wrong semantics. I'd rather `fit, partial fit => exception` just to be clear.

@jnothman `partial_fit` after a `fit` does not raise an exception... Is it probably a bug?

For your 2nd comment, thanks a lot for the review... I'll make the changes :)

> Should fit always leave the model in a state where partial_fit is possible?

@amueller I'm not quite sure. I think it should either raise an error or it should overwrite and do a new fit from the beginning, if one calls partial_fit after fit. If partial_fit starts from where fit left, then it does not make a difference whether you fit or partial_fit, right? ;)

@MechCoder @amueller From what I observed `fit` always restarts the estimator. `partial_fit` continues from the previous setup irrespective of whether the previous setup was a `fit` or a `partial_fit`.

But as you and others  suggested, perhaps `partial_fit` after `fit` should raise an exception?

We could either.
1. Raise an exception.
2. Or overwrite the previously fit model if `partial_fit` is being called after `fit` or `fit` is being called after `partial_fit`.

I'm inclined towards the second one but I'm not sure what is the best thing to do.
I feel 2b is already implemented... I guess its between 2a or 1... Anyway thanks for your comments :)

A code revision related question... When revisions are suggested to the code, am I expected to add a new commit reflecting those revision or do I (soft) reset my previous work, make the changes and recommit?

I think, you can do it either way. But if those revisions are minor, and if you feel it worthless to add a new commit for those (like pep8, cosmits and stuff), you can just amend your commit and push by force (at least, that's what I do).
Thanks... I'll also follow the same :)

The point is that the interaction between `fit` and `partial_fit` hasn't been previously addressed. The assumption is that the user will choose one or the other, but not both. Forcing a particular behaviour by way of the proposed tests will make the matter more consistent, but is also perhaps more of a framework than is actually needed, because the case is somewhat pathological.

@jnothman To your earlier comment, 

> Perhaps we should use something like {code}

Could you expand a little by what you meant?

I understood the part where you said all those estimators should not be tested assuming they are predictors and that we should separately test them based on whether they are a Transformer or Predictor ...

But I fail to understand the two code snippets...
If you meant that we could filter out Transformer like estimators which implement `partial_fit`... I just modified the `method_filter` to accept `!` as a prefix to the method names...

[ @amueller perhaps such a functionality could be useful for `type_filter` too? ]

So for estimators that are not Transformers:
`ests = all_estimators(method_filter=["predict", "!transform", "partial_fit"])` 

And for Transformers with `partial_fit` capability :
`ests = all_estimators(method_filter=["transform", "partial_fit"], type_filter="transformer")`
`# The type filter is perhaps redundant here`

Excuse me if I understood your comment incorrectly...

@amueller I added some tests for `all_estimators`  function as discussed [here](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/3934#issuecomment-65793529). Kindly take a look when you find time... I've also added `!` prefixing for `type_filter` and `method_filter`....

~~( The pfit tests are WIP though... )~~
Travis has a list of errors in test pertaining to somewhere in which `Estimator` is an instance, rather than a class.

@jnothman:

> Travis has a list of errors in test pertaining to somewhere in which `Estimator` is an instance

that should be fixed by now...

BTW could you kindly take a look at these comments if you are free:
- [On whether `partial_fit` after `fit` should raise an error...](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/3907#issuecomment-65773662)
- [This comment](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/3907#issuecomment-65910938) in response to [this suggestion.](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/3907#issuecomment-65751574)

When I said:

> You're assuming all partial_fit estimators are predictors.

I meant that the way you test they are well behaved is by ensuring the `score` is identical (in `check_estimators_pfit_reset_when_fit` for example). Rather, we should be checking that the output of `predict`, `transform`, etc is consistent.

issues.title: ENH Adds infrequent categories to OneHotEncoder
issues.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-checklist
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.
Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Resolves https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/12153
Supersedes https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/13833 
Closes https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/19286

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This PR adds the infrequent categories to `OneHotEncoder` by:

1. Adds `return_counts` to `_encode` to return the counts of the categories.
2. Adjust `_BaseEncoder._fit` and `_BaseEncoder._transform` to accept callables, which can adjust the processing of categories and unknown categories.
3. <s>Deprecates 'ignore' in favor of 'auto'. 'auto' behaves like 'ignore' when there are no infrequent categories in training. If there are infrequent categories in training, then unknown categories are considered infrequent.</s>
4. For the inverse transform and feature names, the infrequent category with the highest cardinality will be used.

### Update

As of [`ef86eb1` (#16018)](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/16018/commits/ef86eb1fee42c6be9012b95acdf1652abe8f36b0) `'ignore'` is option remains and an `infrequent_if_exist` option was added to `handle_unknown`. The `infrequent_if_exist` behaves just like `'ignore'` when there are no infrequent categories for a feature. If a feature does have infrequent categories, then unknown categories will be mapped to the infrequent category.

<s>#### Why deprecated `'ignore'`?

The motivation to deprecate `'ignore'` is connected to how it interacts with infrequent categories. In the following example, feature 0 has infrequent categories and feature 1 does not. This means that feature 0 will map the unknown category to be infrequent, while feature 1 "ignores" the unknown category:

```py
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import pandas as pd

X = pd.DataFrame({
    "col1": ['a'] * 30 + ['b'] * 15 + ['c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g'],
    "col2": ['one'] * 25 + ['two'] * 25
})

ohe = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, min_frequency=2, handle_unknown='auto').fit(X)
ohe.transform([['g', 'three']])
# array([[0., 0., 1., 0., 0.]])
```

**If** we were to keep `'ignore'`, we would run into the following behavior:

```py
# This errors right now
ohe = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, min_frequency=2, handle_unknown='ignore').fit(X)
ohe.transform([['g', 'three']])
# array([[0., 0., 0., 0., 0.]])
```

In this case, all unknown categories are mapped to zero, regardless of there being a infrequent category for the feature. A while ago me and @amueller discussed this and concluded that this behavior is not desirable.</s>

<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is
necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value
all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to
review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering,
convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either
case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
For more information, see our FAQ on this topic:
http://scikit-learn.org/dev/faq.html#why-is-my-pull-request-not-getting-any-attention.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

comments_data.body:
> What is the interaction with drop?

Ok, this is not supported ATM (As Joel suggested, please document this).

I am however concerned about potential future complexity. Supporting interactions with `drop` is one of the reasons https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/13833 was so tricky. @thomasjpfan do you think things will be easier with the implementation proposed in this PR? I haven't looked at the code in details so I don't have an informed opinion yet

> I am however concerned about potential future complexity.

Currently, if `handle_unknown=='ignore'`, then drop must be None. Going with this, lets assume that `handle_unknown=='error'` then we can try to support drop as follows:

1. `drop='first'`, will always drop a frequent column, because the infrequent column is always at the end of the encoding.
2. `drop='infrequent'` the last column will be dropped. (infrequent column is always at the end of the encoding)
2. drop is a list -> if dropped category is frequent, drop it. if dropped category is infrequent AND its the only infrequent category drop it, otherwise keep the infrequent category.

Sorry I wasn't clear, I was more concerned about the complexity of the code, from a maintainability point of view

See e.g. https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/13833/files#diff-d12408664448c94dbd880579e1b2e4d9R452
Implementation-wise, I do not see an issue with including the drop support. I would adjust `_compute_drop_idx` to take into account of the infrequent categories (if they exist).

I think the things left to discuss for this PR is:

1. Is `max_levels` a good name?
2. Is using the most frequent infrequent category a good default for `get_feature_names` and `inverse_transform`? I thought of using a string such as "infrequent" or if that exist then a named mangled str: "infrequent_sklearn". The issue with this, is if the categories were numerical, the `inverse_transform` will become of object dtype.

> Is using the most frequent infrequent category a good default for get_feature_names and inverse_transform? I thought of using a string such as "infrequent" or if that exist then a named mangled str: "infrequent_sklearn". The issue with this, is if the categories were numerical, the inverse_transform will become of object dtype.

I don't like it for get_feature_names. Don't mind for inverse_transform

Updated PR:

1. `max_categories` is now used to control the maximum number of categories for a given input feature.
2. Uses `infrequent` for the category name for infrequent categories and will use `infrequent_sklearn` if `infrequent` already exist as a category. This is used in `get_feature_names` and in `inverse_transform`.

This PR has been updated with:

1. Broke up `_encode` into two functions: `_unique` and `_encode`. The `_unique` has the API of `np.unique` but can handle object dtypes. `_encode` only does encoding. This should make them a bit easier to reason about.

2. Fixes merge conflicts and uses private methods instead of private properties.

As a note for reviewers: The reason this PR deprecates `'ignore'` in favor of `'auto'` is shown in this example:

```py
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import numpy as np

X = np.array([[0] * 40 + [1] * 30 + [2] * 5 + [3] * 5,
              [0] * 40 + [1] * 40]).T
ohe = OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown='auto',
                    sparse=False,
                    max_categories=3).fit(X)

# In the first column there were infrequent categories in training, thus
# unknown categories will be mapped to the infrequent category
ohe.transform([[14, 0]])
# array([[0., 0., 1., 1., 0.]])

# In the second column, there were no infrequen categories in training, 
# thus unknown categories are set to all zeros. This is the same behavior
# as we have now with 'ignore'
ohe.transform([[0, 14]])
# array([[1., 0., 0., 0., 0.]])
```

---

An alternative is to keep `'ignore'`, where we would ignore unknown categories
during transform time:

```py
# this will error explicity error in this PR
ohe = OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown='ignore',
                    sparse=False,
                    max_categories=3).fit(X)

# In the first column there were infrequent categories but with 
# 'ignore' unknown categories would encode to all 0s.
ohe.transform([[14, 0]])
# array([[0., 0., 0., 1., 0.]])
```
everything failing ;)
Let's leave this until after #17317 is merged?

> Let's leave this until after #17317 is merged?

Okay, we can wait for missing value support first.
#17317 is merged ;) I guess it's a bit late for 0.24 now?
@thomasjpfan what is the behaviour of `handle_unknown="auto"` and `drop="first"/"if_binary"`?

>  what is the behaviour of handle_unknown="auto" and drop="first"/"if_binary"?

The same as `ignore`, which is to raise an error.

The motivation to deprecate `'ignore'` is connected to how it interacts with infrequent categories. In the following example, feature 0 has infrequent categories and feature 1 does not. This means that feature 0 will map the unknown category to be infrequent, while feature 1 "ignores" the unknown category:

```py
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
import pandas as pd

X = pd.DataFrame({
    "col1": ['a'] * 30 + ['b'] * 15 + ['c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g'],
    "col2": ['one'] * 25 + ['two'] * 25
})

ohe = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, min_frequency=2, handle_unknown='auto').fit(X)
ohe.transform([['g', 'three']])
# array([[0., 0., 1., 0., 0.]])
```

**If** we were to keep `'ignore'`, we would run into the following behavior:

```py
# This errors right now
ohe = OneHotEncoder(sparse=False, min_frequency=2, handle_unknown='ignore').fit(X)
ohe.transform([['g', 'three']])
# array([[0., 0., 0., 0., 0.]])
```

In this case, all unknown categories are mapped to zero, regardless of there being a infrequent category for the feature. A while ago me and @amueller discussed this and concluded that this behavior is not desirable.
I didn't mean to argue against removing ignore. Did I do so?

> I didn't mean to argue against removing ignore. Did I do so?

You didn't argue against it. The explanation was for a future reviewer. (I'll update the opening message with the explanation)
Any idea on an ETA for the release that includes this feature? Thanks!
@lsorber This needs a second reviewer. I'll bring it up during the next scikit-learn monthly meeting :)

issues.title: [MRG] Estimator tags
issues.body:
Fixes #6599, #7737, #6554, #6715

Also see #6510

Todo
* [x] remove fixme's, enable all tests again
* [x] rename tags so they are false by default
* [x] rewrite tagging mechanism
* [ ] rethink _required_parameters

For another PR:
* add tests on compound estimators like pipeline, gridsearchcv, ...
* fix MultiOutputEstimator
* replace _estimator_type with tags
* tag for sample weight support: has_fit_parameter doesn't work for meta-estimators
* remove cross_decomposition special cases (maybe)
* remove positive data special cases
* input type for sparse data?
* binary only classifiers
* biclustering
* make sure that enough tags are defined? ChainClassifier had no ClassifierMixin :-/

I decided to leave the ``_estimator_type`` for later because this PR is already too big.

Fun issue I just thought about: Can we even define the tags for a pipeline?
How do we know if a pipeline can handle missing data? Because the scalers pass it through (and the tag says they "handle" missing data) and the imputers impute it. So either these need different tags or we just punt on defining tags for pipelines and if you want to run a pipeline the author of the pipeline needs to set the tags specifically for that pipeline if they want to run the tests. That seems not the best, though.

comments_data.body:
This starts to look good, though I have no idea what's happening with ``GaussianRandomProjectionHash``.

There's an issue with ``DummyRegressor`` and ``DummyClassifier`` not reaching the accuracy we're testing for (And the same is true for some of the NB classifiers). I'm not entirely sure how to handle that with tags -- interestingly, I haven't used any tags at all so far.
But a tag "this usually yield bad results" seems kinda odd.

Solves #6079 #6715 #7737 #6981 (potentially but not yet for the last one).
Also #7289.
So I'm allowing ``np.float64`` as a parameter to ``__init__`` because that was used in some of the vectorizers. Alternatively we could change the default to a string instead of a type.

This should be of interest to @GaelVaroquaux @jnothman @jakevdp and @mblondel.
It would be great to get some initial feedback.
This PR does three things:
- it changes the common tests to work on instances instead of classes
- it changes all the hard-coded assumptions about estimators by tags and the ``_required_parameters`` class attribute.
- it fixes API inconsistencies to make the tests pass.

If you want, I can make the first thing it's own PR, because this looks like it's gonna be a big one.
Changing to instances instead of classes for tests is motivated by using instance methods for the tags and #7289. With instance-level common tests, we can write
``check_estimator(make_pipeline(PCA(), SVC(kernel="linear")))``, which I think is good.
Though the separate PR for the instance-level tests will be pretty short compared to the rest.

Tests are currently failing because I'm still working on the third bullet point.

OneVsOneClassifier returns a ``decision_function`` of shape ``(n_samples, 2)`` for a two-class problem. It's the only classifier that does so, as far as I can see. ``OneVsOneClassifier`` returns ``(n_samples, 1)``.
hm so will ``_get_tags()`` be part of the API requirements? or do I need to ``hasattr`` every time? hm... should probably not rely on it being present, so a helper it is.

I decided to make ``TfidfTransformer`` support dense input. That was more simple then writing a new input validation tool that always converts to sparse, no matter what the input. Also seems slightly more sensible than the previous behavior. It does mean, though, that if you provide dense input, it provides dense output, which is a change from before.

Ok, so @GaelVaroquaux @jnothman I need some input. My current solution for ``_get_tags`` is not working. This is a bit lengthy but I'm stuck and I don't understand the motivation for our current class hierarchy.

I'm confused by the method resolution order in our class hierarchy.
We always write the ``BaseEstimator`` to the left, which means it comes in the mru before the mixins, which means the mixins can't actually change any of the ``BaseEstimator`` behavior.
So if I declare some basic tags in ``BaseEstimator`` and want to extend them in ``ClassifierMixin``, I need to call ``super`` in ``BaseEstimator``, and then handle the return from the mixin. That seems really weird to me.

I assumed I can call ``super`` in the mixin and they'll all resolve before ``BaseEstimator``, but exactly the opposite is the case.

I can see the following ways to fix this:

1.  actually call ``super`` in the ``BaseEstimator`` and in all mixins and check if ``super`` has the ``_get_tags`` method (it could always be ``object`` as far as I can see). The code in ``BaseEstimator`` then is a bit weird because it needs to take the defaults and overwrite them with what was given by the ``super`` call. This solution feel really wrong to me.

2. Make all mixins inherit from ``BaseEstimator`` and remove ``BaseEstimator`` from all the estimators (if we add it to the mixins, the compiler requires us to remove it from the estimators to have a well-defined mru). This puts ``BaseEstimator`` on the top of the class hierarchy and it will always resolve last and everything is good.

3. Change the inheritance order in all estimators to have ``BaseEstimator`` at the very right. That puts it last in the mru and everthing is good.

4. Add a base-class (I call it ``KingOfDiamonds``) on top of BaseEstimator and all the mixins, and implement the default ``_get_tags()`` there. ``BaseEstimator`` doesn't even need to implement ``_get_tags`` then, only ``KingOfDiamonds`` needs to. It will always be last in mru and everything is good.

From a code perspective 4 is least intrusive (least number of lines changed), but it adds another layer to the inheritance hierarchy.
3 is the least intrusive in terms of class hierarchy, it "only" changes the mru. It relies on the order of the classes in multiple inheritance, though, which seems somewhat fragile (*).
2 is somewhere in between because it changes both the inheritance structure and the code, but it's relatively robust and doesn't introduce another class.

* With the current setup, if two mixins try to change the same tag, but in opposite directions, then the order of the mixins will matter. That seems like a bad idea that can be avoided in practice, though.

What is the motivation to have BaseEstimator to the left in the first place, and why don't we let the mixins inherit from it?

I think mixins are meant to come before base classes in MRO, although I've not confirmed this intuition wiht online resources (I'm offline). From the perspective of purity, 3 is therefore my preferred solution, though I appreciate it is technically not backwards compatible, and is somewhat brittle.

I think another partial solution is that _get_tags could be conventionally defined with a helper, like:

```python
def _get_tags(self):
    return base.extend_tags(self, tags={'a': 5, 'b': 6}, allow_overwrite=['b'])
```

`extend_tags` would be implemented to allow super's _get_tags to not exist. `allow_overwrite` would ensure that no tag overwriting can take place, except where whitelisted. At least *if* I understand the problem, this should help...?
And I meant to say it's great that you're finding all these bugs!
@jnothman yeah so far mostly meta-estimators and "weird" estimators that we didn't test :-/

> I think another partial solution is that _get_tags could be conventionally defined with a helper, like:

> def _get_tags(self):
    return base.extend_tags(self, tags={'a': 5, 'b': 6}, allow_overwrite=['b'])

> extend_tags would be implemented to allow super's _get_tags to not exist. allow_overwrite would ensure that no tag overwriting can take place, except where whitelisted. At least if I understand the problem, this should help...?

I'm not sure I understand the solution. ``base`` is ``sklearn.base``, right?
What would happen if something tries to overwrite something that is already defined? Silently ignored, right?

So with silent pass I guess this would work if ``BaseEstimator`` has everything in ``allow_overwrite``, and all the others have nothing in ``allow_overwrite``. Because ``BaseEstimator._get_tags`` is called last, it would then not overwrite all the tags defined in the mixins which have been defined earlier.
So yes, I think that would work. I don't think it's pretty, though.

What do you not like about the interface? Is it this exact inheritance issue? Having one attribute per tag would have the same issue, right?
I'm actually quite happy with this interface. I was first a bit bummed that I need a helper function but I don't think there's a way around that.

Actually, another way to resolve the issue is to not give ``BaseEstimator`` a ``_get_tags`` at all and assume that all calls are done with the helper.

Here's a blog complaining about people doing mixins wrong (i.e. the way we do it):
https://www.ianlewis.org/en/mixins-and-python

Another person running into this here:
http://nedbatchelder.com/blog/201210/multiple_inheritance_is_hard.html

But "The hitchhikers guide to Python" and therefore ``requests`` does mixins to the right, while the Python Cookbook does Mixins to the left... I'm gonna take this to the twitters
CPython does "to the left" here: https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/3.5/Lib/socketserver.py#l639
David Beazley agrees with us: https://twitter.com/dabeaz/status/809084586487664641

currently I made some breaking changes to see if it's possible to make things go smoothly.
I'll probably create deprecations and add some special cases back into the tests, but the special cases will go away once the deprecation finished.
@vene this is the second step to more contrib friendly tests ;)

Should I try to separate the two new features in this PR? the instance level test and the estimator tags are somewhat independent, though the estimator tags only really make sense with instance level tests. So we could do instance level tests first and estimator tags later? @GaelVaroquaux @agramfort @ogrisel @jnothman ?
ping @mfeurer who might be interested?

The check for the not fitted error right now is not very elegant, but passes.... If something can only transform and not predict without fitting, but is not stateless, the test will fail.
Maybe ``stateless`` is not the right flag? I'm not sure.

But I think this is a reasonable implementation overall, and it should allow all contrib packages to pass the tests. If not, we can iterate.

issues.title: [MRG] add lobpcg svd_solver to PCA and TruncatedSVD
issues.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
fixes #12079, fixes #12080

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
#12079 adds LOBPCG as an SVD solver in PCA
#12080 adds LOBPCG solver to Truncated PCA

lobpcg_svd should also be useful in KernelPCA for faster partial decompositions, see #12068

This PR also includes multiple LOBPCG related bug fixes, including vendoring  sklearn/externals/_lobpcg.py from scipy 1.3.0

#### Any other comments?
@ogrisel Transferred from permanently closed PR #12291

Keep in mind for testing, that  lobpcg_svd falls back to dense eigensolver unless n_components < 3*matrix_size, where matrix_size = min (n_samples, n_features) 

Still to do, better in new focused PRs after this one is merged

1. example plot_faces_decomposition may include lobpcg_svd, just change 

    ('Eigenfaces - PCA using randomized SVD',
     decomposition.PCA(n_components=n_components, svd_solver='randomized',
                       whiten=True),
     True),

to 

    ('Eigenfaces - PCA using randomized SVD',
     decomposition.PCA(n_components=n_components, svd_solver='lobpcg',
                       whiten=True),
     True),

but lobpcg currently fails here for unclear numerical reasons. More testing may be needed for float32 data, like in this example. 

2. All four existing TruncatedSVD examples of scikit-learn in the examples/ folder do run with lobpcg, just by  adding the option ", algorithm='lobpcg' " to TruncatedSVD function call. But none generates the matrix large enough to demonstrate the practical benefits of lobpcg_svd.

issues.title: Base sample-prop implementation and docs (alternative to #21284)
issues.body:
This is an alternative to #21284.

The main motivation behind the changes is what @glemaitre noticed as repetition of some of the routing logic between `get_metadata_request` methods and what would go in `fit`, `transform`, etc.

To review this PR, you probably should start with the `plot_metadata_routing` file.

This PR simplifies the developer API substantially, such that a simple pipeline can be implemented as:

``` python
class SimplePipeline(ClassifierMixin, BaseEstimator):
    _required_parameters = ["estimator"]

    def __init__(self, transformer, classifier):
        self.transformer = transformer
        self.classifier = classifier

    def fit(self, X, y, **fit_params):
        params = process_routing(self, "fit", fit_params)

        self.transformer_ = clone(self.transformer).fit(X, y, **params.transformer.fit)
        X_transformed = self.transformer_.transform(X, **params.transformer.transform)

        self.classifier_ = clone(self.classifier).fit(
            X_transformed, y, **params.classifier.fit
        )
        return self

    def predict(self, X, **predict_params):
        params = process_routing(self, "predict", predict_params)

        X_transformed = self.transformer_.transform(X, **params.transformer.transform)
        return self.classifier_.predict(X_transformed, **params.classifier.predict)

    def get_metadata_routing(self):
        router = (
            MetadataRouter()
            .add(
                transformer=self.transformer,
                method_mapping=MethodMapping()
                .add(method="fit", used_in="fit")
                .add(method="transform", used_in="fit")
                .add(method="transform", used_in="predict"),
            )
            .add(classifier=self.classifier, method_mapping="one-to-one")
        )
        return router.serialize()
```

This PR does NOT change the __user API__ compared to #21284.

cc @jnothman @glemaitre @thomasjpfan @agramfort 

----------
note from the other PR
----------

This PR is into the `sample-props` branch and not `main`. The idea is to break https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/20350 into smaller PRs for easier review and discussion rounds.

This PR adds the base implementation, and some documentation and a few tests. The tests are re-done from the previous PR. You can probably start with `examples/metadata_routing.py` to get a sense of how things work, and then check the implementation.

This PR does NOT touch splitters and scorers, those and all meta-estimators will be done in future PRs.

__EDIT__: `process_routing` is now a function rather than a decorator.
__EDIT__: Some updates and summary of current discussions: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/22083#issuecomment-1008906378
__EDIT__: a timeline of this feature being merged into `main` is written under https://github.com/scikit-learn/enhancement_proposals/pull/65#issuecomment-1026774869
__EDIT__: this PR creates `set_{method}_request` instead of `{method}_requests` now.

comments_data.body:
I will delay a review for next week but the example that you give is really what I would have liked.
The decorator might look magical for some but I really feel that we remove the complexity of the routing from the algorithmic part of the estimator. This way people interested in the algorithmic part are not blocked by some code routing pattern.

Just hoping that my initial review did not get there:

<details>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7454015/147550270-473b1256-1390-4689-8daa-ebd570deeb3d.png)

</details>

> I'm not yet convinced by the `^type` stuff within the router... I think it has been necessitated by combining a few things into one object:
> * the information an estimator needs to give its caller for its caller to route effectively
> * the information an estimator needs to manage its own routing
> * the information an estimator needs to manage its request
> 
> Can you justify these all being rolled into one object, returned by one method? And if all rolled into one object, is it right to mediate it by having objects of different `^type` with different corresponding structure/semantics?

@jnothman in #21284 I started from thinking about these separations and it was implemented based on those concerns. As an alternative, this PR is developed having the developer API in mind as the first issue. I first wrote the example (`plot_metadata_request.py`) and then implemented what that API required.

@glemaitre pointed out that there's some duplication in the logic of `get_metadata_request` and what goes in `fit`, and that the boilerplate code in `fit` requires people to understand the mechanism and distract them from the _math_ part of an estimator. As a result, in this PR I tried to capture all what is required to handle metadata routing in a single method/object, which is the `get_metadata_routing` and its output. Now the developer needs to only implement that method and there's pretty much no other boilerplate code to write. And for the routing mechanism which goes in other methods such as `fit`, the output of that method needs to have the information required for them to work.

This also means there are two types of objects returned by `get_metadata_routing` and therefore we need to store the type in the serialized version of the object.

I'm not too bothered by this since users shouldn't be really looking at the output of this method. Now that the method returns the whole tree, it's easy to write utility methods which would better _explain_ or _visualize_ metadata routing.

For instance, this is the output `pipeline.get_metadata_routing()` in `test_nested_routing`:

``` python
pipeline = SimplePipeline(
    [
        MetaTransformer(
            transformer=TransformerMetadata()
            .fit_requests(brand=True, sample_weight=False)
            .transform_requests(sample_weight=True)
        ),
        WeightedMetaRegressor(
            estimator=RegressorMetadata().fit_requests(
                sample_weight="inner_weights"
            )
        ).fit_requests(sample_weight="outer_weights"),
    ]
)

pprint(pipeline.get_metadata_routing())
{'^type': 'router',
 'predictor': {'mapping': [{'method': 'fit', 'used_in': 'fit'},
                           {'method': 'partial_fit', 'used_in': 'partial_fit'},
                           {'method': 'predict', 'used_in': 'predict'},
                           {'method': 'score', 'used_in': 'score'},
                           {'method': 'split', 'used_in': 'split'},
                           {'method': 'transform', 'used_in': 'transform'},
                           {'method': 'inverse_transform',
                            'used_in': 'inverse_transform'}],
               'routing': {'^self': {'^type': 'request',
                                     'fit': {'sample_weight': 'outer_weights'},
                                     'inverse_transform': {},
                                     'partial_fit': {},
                                     'predict': {},
                                     'score': {'sample_weight': None},
                                     'split': {},
                                     'transform': {}},
                           '^type': 'router',
                           'estimator': {'mapping': [{'method': 'fit',
                                                      'used_in': 'fit'},
                                                     {'method': 'partial_fit',
                                                      'used_in': 'partial_fit'},
                                                     {'method': 'predict',
                                                      'used_in': 'predict'},
                                                     {'method': 'score',
                                                      'used_in': 'score'},
                                                     {'method': 'split',
                                                      'used_in': 'split'},
                                                     {'method': 'transform',
                                                      'used_in': 'transform'},
                                                     {'method': 'inverse_transform',
                                                      'used_in': 'inverse_transform'}],
                                         'routing': {'^type': 'request',
                                                     'fit': {'sample_weight': 'inner_weights'},
                                                     'inverse_transform': {},
                                                     'partial_fit': {},
                                                     'predict': {},
                                                     'score': {'sample_weight': None},
                                                     'split': {},
                                                     'transform': {}}}}},
 'step_0': {'mapping': [{'method': 'fit', 'used_in': 'fit'},
                        {'method': 'transform', 'used_in': 'fit'},
                        {'method': 'transform', 'used_in': 'predict'}],
            'routing': {'^type': 'router',
                        'transformer': {'mapping': [{'method': 'fit',
                                                     'used_in': 'fit'},
                                                    {'method': 'partial_fit',
                                                     'used_in': 'partial_fit'},
                                                    {'method': 'predict',
                                                     'used_in': 'predict'},
                                                    {'method': 'score',
                                                     'used_in': 'score'},
                                                    {'method': 'split',
                                                     'used_in': 'split'},
                                                    {'method': 'transform',
                                                     'used_in': 'transform'},
                                                    {'method': 'inverse_transform',
                                                     'used_in': 'inverse_transform'}],
                                        'routing': {'^type': 'request',
                                                    'fit': {'brand': True,
                                                            'sample_weight': False},
                                                    'inverse_transform': {},
                                                    'partial_fit': {},
                                                    'predict': {},
                                                    'score': {},
                                                    'split': {},
                                                    'transform': {'sample_weight': True}}}}}}
```

The only reason `get_metadata_routing` returns this serialized version is for third party estimators not to have to have a hard dependency on sklearn, otherwise I'd return the object, which would be much nicer to deal with and the user wouldn't need to see `^type`.

Thank you so much for the detailed and prompt response @adrinjalali!

Can we avoid `^type` by using `{"^self": ...}` instead of `{"^type": "request"}`?

I'm not sure yet if having the whole tree of requests returned is the right design. I appreciate that the main idea is to ask the router dev to implement one method only.

Re `@process_routing`: I see the benefit of a decorator for code simplicity, but I am uncomfortable about the wrapper effectively changing the method's signature, which may make the code, and its relation to docstring, much harder to understand for new readers. How far do you think we can go with a single function call within the method? (Let's not consider the "Router and Consumer" case for now.) Something like `self_params, routed_params = process_routing(self, "fit", fit_params)`...

I think that if we require `get_metadata_routing` to return a highly sophisticated structure, as opposed to the minimum info needed by a parent router, we should not expect it to be reimplemented by downstream devs not wanting to depend on scikit-learn.

> I'm not sure yet if having the whole tree of requests returned is the right design. I appreciate that the main idea is to ask the router dev to implement one method only.

Even though it was motivated by easing the work of the developers, another reason I really like it is that it can be used to visualize how metadata routing works and where each input goes. Planning to write a helper function which would give that visualization in a separate PR, and we can even think of having an html repr if we fancy it.

> Can we avoid `^type` by using `{"^self": ...}` instead of `{"^type": "request"}`?

Not really. It's true that `self` is I guess always a `request` type, but the output of a `get_metadata_routing` of a simple estimator is of type `request`, and not a `router`. I did try to have them the same type, but it really didn't make sense and I didn't manage to do it.

I'm not sure why you're bothered by it so much though 😁 

> Re `@process_routing`: I see the benefit of a decorator for code simplicity, but I am uncomfortable about the wrapper effectively changing the method's signature, which may make the code, and its relation to docstring, much harder to understand for new readers. How far do you think we can go with a single function call within the method? (Let's not consider the "Router and Consumer" case for now.) Something like `self_params, routed_params = process_routing(self, "fit", fit_params)`...

Done!

> Planning to write a helper function which would give that visualization in a separate PR, and we can even think of having an html repr if we fancy it.

But this is also possible given an estimator without storing it as a consolidated object. I don't see it as sufficient justification.

> I'm not sure why you're bothered by it so much though 😁

Because the two types are actually one?

> Done!

Nice!

> But this is also possible given an estimator without storing it as a consolidated object. I don't see it as sufficient justification.

We would then have another way of accessing those sub-objects (estimators, scorers, splitters), and that means each estimator would need to expose how to access them in another way, and I'm not sure if that justifies not having the whole tree returned here. I'm not sure why this is a big deal though. To me it's clean, doesn't take much space, and doesn't add much or anything time-wise.

> Because the two types are actually one?

I must be missing something, cause they're really not one. At least as things are implemented now. To the point that right now we have `_get_metadata_request` and `get_metadata_router` which return two different objects of different types on a router+consumer object.

Making them (and `get_metadata_router` of a simple consumer) the same, would complicate things rather than simplify. Note that for a simple estimator, `get_metadata_router` returns a `MetadataRequest` and not a `MetadataRouter`, and hence it doesn't have a `$self` as you suggest.

What am I missing?

There are some changes in this PR now:

- `get_metadata_routing` now returns the object, rather than the serialized version of it. `_metadata_reqeusts.py` is written in a way that people can vendor the file instead of depending on `scikit-learn`. The code avoids usages of `isinstance` to make this easier.
- `_sentinels.py` is removed and we use invalid identifiers instead in `RequestType` enum, which also helps with third party developers being able to not have a hard dependency on scikit-learn.
- in the string representation of routing objects, only non-empty methods are included.

This PR uses the following to create the routing information:

``` python
    def get_metadata_routing(self):
        router = (
            MetadataRouter()
            .add(
                transformer=self.transformer,
                method_mapping=MethodMapping()
                .add(method="fit", used_in="fit")
                .add(method="transform", used_in="fit")
                .add(method="transform", used_in="predict"),
            )
            .add(classifier=self.classifier, method_mapping="one-to-one")
        )
        return router
```

and the following to validate/route metadata:

``` python
    def fit(self, X, y, **fit_params):
        params = process_routing(self, "fit", fit_params)

        self.transformer_ = clone(self.transformer).fit(X, y, **params.transformer.fit)
        X_transformed = self.transformer_.transform(X, **params.transformer.transform)

        self.classifier_ = clone(self.classifier).fit(
            X_transformed, y, **params.classifier.fit
        )
        return self
```

The issue is some people find the first part intuitively understandable as written, and some people would prefer the following variation:

``` python
    def get_metadata_routing(self):
        router = (
            MetadataRouter()
            .add(
                transformer=self.transformer,
                method_mapping=MethodMapping()
                .add(dst="fit", src="fit")
                .add(dst="transform", src="fit")
                .add(dst="transform", src="predict"),
            )
            .add(classifier=self.classifier, method_mapping="one-to-one")
        )
        return router
```

I would like us to make the decision based on how the end-user/developer API is used rather than how it's implemented, and I'd like us to make that decision based on how users would feel about it. I think it would be nice for us to have a discussion on our mailing list and maybe social media to get some feedback before setting things on stone.

Now that I see both implementations side by side, I am very +1 on `src` and `dst` now.

> I think it would be nice for us to have a discussion on our mailing list and maybe social media to get some feedback before setting things on stone.

What kind of questions do you want to ask? I can see getting a simple 1-2 question survey:

#### Survey idea one
We can get feedback on "is this API simple to understand for developers", by showing an implementation of an meta-estimator based on https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/22083#issuecomment-1008906378 and ask what they think it does. After the first question, we can describe what the routing does and then ask a follow up comparing  (`src`, `dst`) and (`method`, `used_in`).

#### Survey idea two
Alternatively, we can describe what routing does, show both  (`src`, `dst`) and (`method`, `used_in`) and ask which one is easier to understand.

In any case, the most useful feedback would be from third-party estimator developers.
I merged `main` to see if #22192 works as expected after the merge.

Ooops, I had not realized this was a PR to a branch, let me remove the merge commit with a force push of c834ba31e5487009b5e23802b4182a70ddcf6918. Sorry for that.

Edit: done.

> I merged main to see if #22192 works as expected after the merge.

This should cost a round of 🍻 to @ogrisel  :)

The build worked with an invalidated cache. Let's see if the subsequent commit runs faster by benefiting from the cache of the previous one and still run correctly.

Edit: that works now.
Would you have time to do a bit of review on the PR @jnothman ?

> How stable do we see return values from developer API being? Are those serialised routing specs going to at least be extensible to the case where we annotate params as sample-aligned or not?

We're no longer deserializing those string representations. So I'm not sure if the need to be extensible.

@lorentzenchr note that this PR will not close the issue you linked to it. It doesn't touch scorers, metaestimators, or cross_val* functions. 

I've listed issues being closed by this effort in #20350.
@adrinjalali Thanks. It was a bit early. I'll better focus on this PR:wink:

If I remember correctly, when I created [PR 13432](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/13432) a while back, I noticed that [learning curves](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.model_selection.learning_curve.html) seemed to be missing support for sample weights.  Will this PR address that use case too?  If so, maybe updating the docs to show how to incorporate sample weights there might be helpful.
@ryan-deak-zefr, yes, we will eventually get around to adding support in learning curves. This PR provides the basis for supporting weights and other metadata routing all over the place.

@jnothman per your suggestion I changed the `get_routing_for_object` to raise an error instead of returning an empty request if it doesn't recognize the object. Now I remember the reason the function wasn't raising an error was that I didn't want to break people's code if they used a third party estimator which doesn't implement `get_metadata_routing` (yet). What's your take on that?

>  Now I remember the reason the function wasn't raising an error was that I didn't want to break people's code if they used a third party estimator which doesn't implement get_metadata_routing (yet). What's your take on that?

I think you're right that this should not raise an error, such that `route_params` will return an empty dict for that case. (And this should be tested.)

issues.title: [MRG] Partial dependence plots -- continued
issues.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-checklist
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.
Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

This is the continuation of #5653. Lots of tests and checks have been added, with a few fixes. More detailed changes from #5653 can be found here https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/5653#issuecomment-439183334. 

Closes #5653
Closes #4405

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This PR implements support for partial dependence plots with any regressor or classifier that has `predict_proba`.

#### Any other comments?

Partial dependence plots were only supported for gradient boosting trees and the functions were in `ensemble.partial_dependence`. All backward compatibility is preserved, but those functions are deprecated in favor of the `sklearn.partial_dependence` module.


The `grid` param has been removed in the new implementation.
The `ax` param was replaced by `fig`. The claim that the new plots were plotted on the `ax` argument was wrong.

<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is
necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value
all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to
review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering,
convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either
case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
For more information, see our FAQ on this topic:
http://scikit-learn.org/dev/faq.html#why-is-my-pull-request-not-getting-any-attention.

Thanks for contributing!
-->


#### Some possible improvements

In separate PRs:

- Add support for 3D plots instead of just a contour
- Add support for https://arxiv.org/pdf/1309.6392.pdf. Basically, instead of averaging the responses, we actually plot all of them. That would only be relevant for 1-way PDP.
- Add support for plotting the same PDP of different estimators on the same matplotlib `ax` object.

comments_data.body:
> removed support for RandomForestRegressor with recursion because it actually doesn't work in multioutput settings

but it works in the single output setting? So we should support it then, right?

The original code only supports instances of `BaseGradientBoosting`. `RandomForestRegressor` happens to also **alsmost** work but that's just some kind of coincidence.

I think it's not worth it allowing `RandomForestRegressor` (or any random forest estimator) with `recursion` here, because it only partially works.

It would be better IMO to re-write the partial dependence code to work for any tree, and then we could port it back to `DecisionTreeXXX` and all of the tree ensembles, not just `GradientBoostingXXXX`.

Ah, I thought that was already working ;) So for now we have recursion only for gradient boosting, and the general formula for everything.
Fixing this for all trees would be nice but can be a follow-up PR.
I think coverage is decreasing because the tests involving matplotlib aren't run by travis (which generates the coverage report)
not sure where the conflict is coming from. Can you remind me, is this ready for review?

Funky indeed.

Yes, this is ready for reviews. Note that almost all the plot-related code in `plot_partial_dependence()` has been left unchanged from the original.

Do we want some more examples? Maybe comparing several classifiers on the same dataset? I have no idea what that would even look like, so I think it might be a good example? I find these are easier to interpret for regression, so maybe doing a random forest vs a linear model vs an SVM or neural net?

There is an extension to the concept of partial dependence which I use for understanding models. It is best described by example. Suppose we have a binary variable X which we want the partial dependence of. Normally we average the predicted values for both X=0 and X=1 for the data points in each group. However, it is pretty common that data points themselves can be quite different. ie df[df['X']=1] and df[df['X']=0] have very different distributions in the dimensions other than X. This implies that the partial dependence of X is saying as much about the data distribution as it is about the model. To take out this effect I put all data in all points at each value of X instead of just the ones "measured" at that value. Explicitly I add the following two data sets to my data

new_X0 = df[df['X']==1]
new_X0['X']=0

new_X1 = df[df['X']==0]
new_X1['X']=1

This would double the size of my data and 'balance' it to take out the biases in the data. For context, if you are using the PDP to calculate the price index this is the same as ensuring the "basket of goods" is the same in each year. 

This increases the data an hence computation time by a factor of df['X'].nunique() so it can be an issue if using the brute force method. For the estimate method it would actually be marginally faster since the average values would all be the same so the average only needs to be done once. 

I was hoping this functionality could be added as a flag in the function. I could help with the development of this if desired. Currently I just modify the data set before passing it to the PDP function but it is cumbersome.

@DrEhrfurchtgebietend would you have any reference for this technique?

In any case I think you'll want to open a new issue about this (maybe once this PR is merged?) because it's unlikely that those changes would happen in this PR.
@NicolasHug I have no reference. I came up with the idea myself but I would be surprised if I was the first to notice this. I will bring it up again once this PR is merged.

>Do we want some more examples?

Sure, I'll try to find something

> There's no test that "it does the right thing", right? 

There is only [this test](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/12599/files#diff-8c38cc6ff69331d3508160870f41eca2R160) but I agree it's quite light.

>If the output depends only one one feature in a known way (say linear or quadratic) then the partial dependence for that feature should show that and all the other plots should be constant, right?

How would you test for that? By fitting e.g. a linear regression on the output of `partial_dependence()` and computing R squared?

I would be in favor of deprecating the `partial_dependence` function and making it private.

I doubt it is actually used, and the interface is slightly different from `plot_partial_dependence`: it accepts a `grid` parameter that is optional, `X` is also optional but only under certain conditions, etc...
happy to make it private in the new module.

Hm I just remembered it's used in the example to make the 3D plot.

Would it be OK if I add something like a `'projection'` param that can be either '2d' or '3d' and that uses `contour` or `plot_surface` accordingly?

This way we can keep the example intact while still getting rid of `partial_dependence`.

> I would be in favor of deprecating the `partial_dependence` function and making it private.
> 
> I doubt it is actually used, and the interface is slightly different from `plot_partial_dependence`: it accepts a `grid` parameter that is optional, `X` is also optional but only under certain conditions, etc...

But it lets the user do whatever they want with the outputs... ie. use something other than matplotlib to plot it, or just output to csv if you want to. No big deal if the `plot_partial_dependence` function allows for output to something more raw than a matplotlib object, just a thought.

Ok that's a fair point.

I didn't deprecate it, but removed the `grid` parameter instead
I've updated the example to also use `MLPRegressor`, and also fixed the `ax` parameter (replaced it by `fig` which is more exact)

@amueller @jnothman I think I've addresed all the comments so far. Quick recap since last round:

- I've added warnings in the doc about using non-constant init estimators with 'recursion' method
- removed grid parameter in `partial_dependenc()`
- removed 'ax' parameter in `plot_partial_dependence()` and changed it to 'fig' because it makes more sense
- updated example with the PDPs of a `MLPRegressor`.

Like mentioned earlier, coverage is decreasing because the PR adds some matplotlib tests which aren't run by travis.
I should note to the curious reviewer: the codecov patch failure is due to some tests requiring matplotlib.
thanks a lot for the reviews @jnothman !

comments_data.body:
thanks for the early PR

let me know when you need a review ie when you addressed the standard things (tests, example, some basic doc)
I'd also be interested in reviewing this when you've moved past the WIP stage.
I think it is ready for a first review @agramfort @jmschrei !

I would like to see some more extensive unit tests, particularly in cases where the algorithm should fail (wrong dimensions or other incorrect types of data passed in). I'll be able to look more at the performance of the code once you merge the mixin with the other class, and change the API to always take in an X matrix.
I'd also like to see an example of it performing against a/many current algorithm(s), so that it is clear it is a valuable contribution.

If you have a dataset X and want to remove outliers from it, you don't want to do

```
fit(X)
predict(X)
```

because then each sample is considered in its own neighbourhoud: in predict(X), X is considered as 'new observations'.

What the user wants is:

```
for each x in X,
fit(X-{x})
predict(x)
```

which is allowed by

```
fit(X)
predict()
```

It is like looking for k-nearest-neighbors of points in a dataset X: you can do:

```
neigh = NearestNeighbors()
neigh.fit(X)
neigh.kneighbors()
```

which is different from

```
neigh = NearestNeighbors()
neigh.fit(X)
neigh.kneighbors(X)
```

I can make `predict()` have as signature

> def predict(self, X):

and allows taking X=None in argument... Is it allowed ?

> If you have a dataset X and want to remove outliers from it, you don't want to do
> 
> fit(X)
> predict(X)

implement a fit_predict(X) method is the way to go.
Ok thanks !

I merged the mixin with LOF class, changed the API and added a comparison example.
@agramfort @jmschrei what do you think?

I haven't finished my review, but I think `fit` and `predict` are still feasible, but you just have to ignore points whose distance away is 0. It would maintain the same API as all other estimators, which I think is hugely beneficial.

The problem is that we have indeed to ignore the first neighbor if min dist is 0 **only if** the user wants to detect outliers in a dataset (without training) (second case below), **not** if it happens that a new sample has already been sampled during training. Formally, we want to be able to differentiate

```
fit(X)
predict(X)
```

from

```
fit_predict(X)
```

which means:

```
for each x in X,
fit(X-{x})
predict(x)
```

We have similar issues with KNeighbors and `kneighbors_graph`, right? (btw, there are a bunch of algorithms that store `X_fit_` or `_fit_X_`. I think at some point we even had some warning if someone was passing in the training data to `predict` (or `transform`?)

We could go the way of `kneighbors_graph` and do `predict()` to mean calling predict on the training X. it's odd if `fit(X).predict(X)` is not the same as `fit_predict(X)`.

I pushed a commit which changes the API to give sense to fit(X).predict()
as proposed by @amueller: 
`fit(X).predict()` and `fit(X).decision_function()` do prediction on X without
 considering samples as their own neighbors (ie without considering X as a
 new dataset as does `fit(X).predict(X)`)

It also adds a contamination parameter (like in EllipticEnvelope and in WIP #5638 on IsolationForest) so that predict returns binary values.

issues.title: FEA Generalize the use of precomputed sparse distance matr…

labels.name: High Priority
labels.description: High priority issues and pull requests

issues.body:
This PR implements solution (A) proposed in #10463.

Fixes #2792, #7426, #9691, #9994, #10463, #13596
Closes #3922, #7876, #8999, #10206
Gives a workaround for #8611

It generalizes the use of precomputed sparse distance matrices, and proposes to use pipelines to chain nearest neighbors with other estimators.
More precisely, it introduces new estimators `KNeighborsTransformer` and `RadiusNeighborsTransformer`, which transforms an input X into a (weighted) graph of its nearest neighbors. The output is a sparse distance/affinity matrix.

The proposed usecase is the following:
```py
from sklearn.pipeline import make_pipeline
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsTransformer
from sklearn.manifold import TSNE

est_chain = make_pipeline(
    KNeighborsTransformer(n_neighbors=n_neighbors, mode='distance',
                          metric=metric, include_self=False),
    TSNE(metric='precomputed', method="barnes_hut"),
    memory='path/to/cache')

est_compact = TSNE(metric=metric, method="barnes_hut")
```
In this example `est_chain` and `est_compact` are equivalent, but `est_chain` gives more control on the nearest neighbors estimator. Moreover, it can use the pipeline caching properties, to reuse the same nearest neighbors matrix for different TSNE parameters. Finally, it is possible to replace `KNeighborsTransformer` with a custom nearest neighbors estimator returning the graph of connections with the nearest neighbors.
___
This pipeline works with:
- `TSNE`, `Isomap`, `SpectralEmbedding`
- `DBSCAN`, `SpectralClustering`,
- `KNeighborsClassifier`, `RadiusNeighborsClassifier`, `KNeighborsRegressor`, `RadiusNeighborsRegressor`, `LocalOutlierFactor`

This pipeline cannot work with:
- `LocallyLinearEmbedding` (which needs the original X)
___
Possible improvements:
- Add a kernel parameter to transform distances into affinities
- Add symmetric option for affinities (to remove warning in SpectralEmbedding, SpectralClustering)

comments_data.body:
Nice work @TomDLT and thanks for the summary in https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/10463.

> The key caveat is that it requires all required neighborhoods to be computed in advance. This may be a memory burden still for something like DBSCAN (although our current implementation is already memory heavy).
> It would be really good if we could illustrate plugging in an approximate nearest neighbors estimator, but it would likely include adding a pyann or similar dependency, unless we attempt to write a very short LSH just to prove the point.

The API with a transformer looks quite nice, and caching the NN can certainly help for repeated estimators fits with different parameters.  However, as far as ANN are concerned I don't find it immediately obvious that pre-computing a sparse distance matrix with ANN, and e.g. using it in DBSCAN has an equivalent performance to directly using the ANN in the estimator. 

For instance, I would be curious to know the results of the following benchmark. Take some low dimensional data where we know that kd_tree will perform well (e.g. `n_features=2`). Use it to pre-compute the sparse distance matrix and fit DBSCAN. Compare the performance to using  kd_tree directly in the DBSCAN.  This would allow estimating the overhead of this approach, without necessarily having to add an ANN implementation.

I'm not sure what you're trying to show about ANN with that, @rth. Currently DBSCAN calculates the nearest neighbors of all X once and computes the clustering from that. There is some overhead when passing in sparse D rather than just passing in features X: unpacking, thresholding on radius and repacking.

This is not how it was originally implemented, mind you, and was optimised for speed rather than memory (see e.g. #5275). Perhaps with a *NeighborsTransformer, we could go back to that original low memory implementation, but get most of the speed benefits as long as the user provides the precomputed sparse matrix.

One disadvantage of this design as opposed to #8999 is that there the host algorithm can pass in a `radius` or a `n_neighbors`, which would save time relative to precomputing and then filtering/checking the precomputed input. We also do not currently require that the precomputed input is in sorted order, so there is a `O(n_train_samples log n_train_samples)` cost per query in order to sort it. We could make some constraints on precomputed sparse matrix input  corresponding to `*neighbors_graph(None, mode='distance')` output (or check it and raise a warning but accept it) if we'd rather: it needs to be in CSR with each row's data increasing, and at train time the diagonal needs to be implicit, not stored zeros.

One advantage of this design as opposed to #8999 is that it may allow you to precompute more neighbors than you need, then estimate downstream with various parameters (e.g. DBSCAN.eps); thus it works well with caching pipelines. Of course you could do that with #8999 by implementing your own precomputed neighborhood wrapper.

Regardless of all this, I think it would be good to give an example of, or at least describe, the use of this for exploiting approximate nearest neighbor approaches. Writing up a simple (but not super-efficient) gaussian projection hash, or a minhash, might not be excessive.

Thanks for the feedback.

additional TODO:
- [x] Separate into `RadiusNeighborsTransformer` and `KNeighborsTransformer`
- [x] Consider adding a constraint on graph sorting order
- [x] Adapt as much of #10206 as possible, in particular unpacking with different n_neighbors/radius
- [x] Add small speed benchmark to quantify unpacking overhead
- [x] Add example with ANN
Everything is red (and that might be my fault)

About sorting distances in the neighbors graph, [here is a benchmark](https://gist.github.com/TomDLT/e9afe3cefefce7e5e815c3a07e79191c).

The conclusion is:
- let's sort only if necessary as suggested by Joel
- let's use Joel's method for radius type graphs (cf [here](https://github.com/TomDLT/scikit-learn/blob/c1e7f545942a80e6e79d486a7390c44de9678506/sklearn/neighbors/base.py#L138-L141))
- let's use my method for n_neighbors type graphs (cs [here](https://github.com/TomDLT/scikit-learn/blob/c1e7f545942a80e6e79d486a7390c44de9678506/sklearn/neighbors/base.py#L128-L135))

___
Interestingly, `scipy.sparse.csr_matrix.min` does not preserve the order:
```py
from scipy.sparse import csr_matrix
from sklearn.neighbors.base import _is_sorted, _check_precomputed
X = csr_matrix(np.random.randn(10, 10))

print(_is_sorted(X))  # False
X = _check_precomputed(X)
print(_is_sorted(X))  # True
a = X.min()
print(_is_sorted(X))  # False
```
Indeed, it calls `self._deduped_data`, which calls `self.sum_duplicates`, which calls `self.sort_indices`.

That's why I check X.data.min() < 0 and not X.min() < 0 in `pairwise_distances`.
___
About the CircleCI failure, I though sphinx-gallery would only run files starting with 'plot'.
Any idea why sphinx-gallery runs `examples/neighbors/neighbors_in_pipeline_api.py` but not `examples/hetero_feature_union.py` ?

Good catch! I wrote the tests for scipy.sparse to make sure they handle
non-canonical data correctly, so this is again my fault. It is extra
support for the idea that we should not raise an error if the input is not
sorted by data... But perhaps it also means we should not raise a warning,
and that it might be acceptable to sort in-place (?).

> let's use my method for n_neighbors type graphs (cs here)

I can't see how this method is different apart from a couple of typo fixes. I'm curious to see what additional tricks you found. But all's good.

Tests are failing. Do you want reviews despite?
Merge conflict
Test failures

> Btw, do you have use cases for include_self? Calling transform(Xtrain) will always include self. I think at least the default should be False so that changing mode does not have side effects when everything else is default. But I know you've got this behaviour for compatibility.... Which altogether makes me think it's best left out

I added `include_self` to be able to have the equivalence between `Estimator()` and `make_pipeline(NeighborsTransformer(), Estimator('precomputed'))`.

To have the equivalence, we need:

Estimator | mode | include_self
------------ | ------------- | -------------
`SpectralClustering`, `SpectralEmbedding` | 'connectivity' | True
`DBSCAN`, `Isomap`, `TSNE`, `LOF` | 'distance' | False
`KNeighborsClassifier`, `KNeighborsRegressor` | 'distance' | True
`RadiusNeighborsClassifier`, `RadiusNeighborsRegressor` | 'distance' | True

In the end I am not sure we need the magic with `include_self=None` since it does not work for the classifiers and regressors...

hmm... that analysis is a bit troubling. do we really need
include_self=True in neighbours classifiers/regressors, or can we easily
make them more robust?

Maybe it's fine to keep include_self=None for spectral, but even there I
don't really get why we should need an object's connectivity to itself to
be expressed.

I updated this analysis (cf 09dd78d355d8f570ad90eb15db11a5b5928c507b) and it turns out I was wrong:

Estimator | mode | include_self
------------ | ------------- | -------------
`SpectralClustering`, `SpectralEmbedding` | 'connectivity' | True
`DBSCAN`, `Isomap`, `TSNE`, `LOF` | 'distance' | False
`KNeighborsClassifier`, `KNeighborsRegressor` | 'distance' | True or False
`RadiusNeighborsClassifier`, `RadiusNeighborsRegressor` | 'distance' | True or False

Actually, the `True or False` makes sense since these classes use `fit().predict()` and not `fit_predict()`.

About the spectral classes, `include_self=True` is explicitly demanded ([here](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/97523985b39ecde369d83352d7c3baf403b60a22/sklearn/cluster/spectral.py#L453) and [here](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/97523985b39ecde369d83352d7c3baf403b60a22/sklearn/manifold/spectral_embedding_.py#L462)). If we precompute with `include_self=False`, the number of neighbors is increase by 1 compared to `include_self=True`, which changes the results, even though the function `scipy.sparse.csgraph.laplacian` might be invariant to an implicit diagonal of zero or an explicit diagonal of ones.
In fact, the spectral models are equivalent if `n_neighbors=n_neighbors + 1, include_self=True` or `n_neighbors=n_neighbors, include_self=False`.

sounds a bit more reasonable. I think we should assume the distance case is
the usual one. let's continue to support include_self=None (or use
include_self='default' for clearer semantics)

I can't remember what else I needed to review here. I'm also not sure when
i can get to it

You said earlier:
>I still need to look again at the neighbors changes.
>I've not yet tried to think about whether there are tests missing.

Also ping @ogrisel

Tests fixed, thanks!

- I removed `test_t_sne.py::test_no_sparse_on_barnes_hut` since NearestNeighbors does accept CSR matrix with method "brute". This is tested in `test_t_sne.py::test_fit_csr_matrix`.
- I fixed `check_non_negative` and added a test.
- I added `pairwise_estimator_convert_X` in `check_regressors_no_decision_function`.

I don't think a metaestimator is a good idea, the pipeline is doing exactly what we need...
Nearest Neighbors computation exactly fits in the Transformer category, and complies with `fit_transform` == `fit + transform` in the `include_self=True` case.

I don't mind having `fit_transform` != `fit + transform`, but as we absolutely want to avoid it, I implemented the following solution:
- The transformer always store explicitly the diagonal, and I removed the parameter `include_self`. Therefore, we always have `fit_transform` == `fit + transform`.
- I modified the extraction of precomputed sparse neighbor graph in `self.kneighbors()` to remove the diagonal if `X=None`. This is used in `TSNE`, `Isomap` and `LOF`
- I fixed an bug in `DBSCAN`: When the neighbors graph was precomputed, it assumed that it was computed with `include_self=False` and DBSCAN added the diagonal to be equivalent to `include_self=True`. In particular, if the diagonal was already present, it added the diagonal a second time. I fixed this bug, so `include_self=True` and `include_self=False` are now equivalent. **It will break code but I consider it as a bugfix.**
___
The only caveat is that if you want to use `TSNE`, `Isomap` or `LOF` in a pipeline, you need to ask one more neighbor in the transformer:
```py
    est_chain = make_pipeline(
        KNeighborsTransformer(n_neighbors=n_neighbors + 1, mode='distance'),
        Isomap(n_neighbors=n_neighbors, neighbors_algorithm='precomputed'))

    est_compact = Isomap(n_neighbors=n_neighbors, neighbors_algorithm=algorithm)
```

> I don't have a big problem with having .fit(X).transform(X) != .fit_transform
> (X) in cases such as this... but others (@GaelVaroquaux) believe this is a
> severe contract violation, according to the discussion on stacking (#8960).

It was decided a few years ago that it was a violation (and the contract
was respected in the anomaly detection work, cc @agramfort).

I have no issue changing this contract, because it should be discussed
and announced publicly, because this contract has conditioned our design
in many places.

Also, a "risk analysis" of what can go wrong in terms of misuse should be
run.
